row.field_page_description: For human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) to cause cervical cancer, a precise DNA sequence of the E7 gene may be required, this Cancer Currents post on a new study explains.
row.field_feature_card_description: Researchers identified the sequence of the specific gene linked to the cancer-causing ability of HPV16.
row.field_list_description: By comparing the genomes of women infected with a high-risk type of human papillomavirus (HPV), researchers have found that a precise DNA sequence of a viral gene is associated with cervical cancer.

row.title: Extensive Lymph Node Removal Doesn't Improve Survival in Some Women with Early-Stage Breast Cancer
row.field_short_title: Trial Provides Insights on Lymph Node Removal in Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: For some women with early-stage breast cancer who have a lumpectomy, a sentinel node biopsy is sufficient, as this Cancer Currents article explains.
row.field_feature_card_description: In some women with early-stage disease, conservative approach sufficient, study shows.
row.field_list_description: Long-term results from a large clinical trial confirm that, for some women with early-stage breast cancer who have lumpectomy as their surgical treatment, a less extensive lymph node biopsy approach is sufficient.

row.title: Searching for Less-Toxic Cancer Treatments for Kids
row.field_short_title: Searching for Less-Toxic Cancer Treatments for Kids-Gregory Aune, M.D., Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: Frustration with the toxicities of chemotherapy and radiation spurs cancer survivor and investigator Greg Aune to look for less-toxic therapies for children.
row.field_feature_card_description: Gregory Aune, M.D., Ph.D., focuses on identifying biomarkers of toxicity caused by powerful cancer drugs.

row.title: Conversation with Dr. Shiva Malek and Dr. Christiaan Klijn
row.field_short_title: Conversation with Dr. Shiva Malek and Dr. Christiaan Klijn
row.field_page_description: Inhibiting MEK re-wires regulation of MAPK signaling so that inhibitors of RAF kinases are more effective against cells driven by mutant KRAS.
row.field_feature_card_description: Combined inhibition of MEK and RAF inhibits cells driven by mutant KRAS.
row.field_list_description: Signaling downstream of RAS is subject to many levels of regulation. Inhibiting MEK seems to re-wire that regulation so that inhibitors of RAF kinases are more effective against cells driven by mutant KRAS.

row.title: Trichloroethylene (TCE)
row.field_page_description: Trichloroethylene (TCE) is a chemical used to make refrigerants and as a metal degreaser. It may be found in contaminated soil or water near military bases and in some commercial and household cleaning products. TCE exposure may cause kidney cancer and increase the risk of lymphoma and liver cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Trichloroethylene (TCE) is widely used as a degreasing agent and may accumulate in soil and groundwater near places it is used. TCE exposure may cause kidney cancer and increase the risk of lymphoma and liver cancer.
row.field_list_description: Learn about trichloroethylene (TCE), a chemical used to make refrigerants and as a degreaser. Exposure to TCE may cause kidney cancer and increase the risk of lymphoma and liver cancer. Although most TCE in the United States is used in manufacturing refrigerants, it may be found in contaminated soil or groundwater near military bases and in some commercial and household cleaning products.

row.title: Plans for NCI’s Fiscal Year 2019 Budget
row.field_short_title: Plans for NCI’s Fiscal Year 2019 Budget
row.field_page_description: NCI Director Dr. Ned Sharpless on NCI’s FY2019 budget and important budgetary decisions, including those related to the Cancer Moonshot and young investigators.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI Director Dr. Ned Sharpless explains important decisions for the coming fiscal year.
row.field_list_description: NCI Director Dr. Ned Sharpless describes important decisions NCI leaders have recently made with respect to the institute’s fiscal year 2019 budget, including those related to the Cancer Moonshot and early-stage investigators.

row.title: About Rare Cancers
row.field_page_description: Rare cancers are those that affect fewer than 40,000 people per year in the U.S. As a group, they make up just over a quarter of all cancers. Because rates of cancer in children are very low, all children’s cancers are considered rare. A quarter of all cancer deaths each year are due to rare cancers. Although new treat
row.field_feature_card_description: Rare cancers are those that affect fewer than 40,000 people per year in the U.S. As a group, they make up just over a quarter of all cancers. The MyPART network was started to make it easier to find treatments for rare cancers.

row.title: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma
row.field_page_description: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma, or FLHCC, is a rare cancer of the liver that usually grows in teens and adults under 40 years old. It is unsusal because it occurs in people who have healthy livers. Learn more about how this cancer forms, is treated, and the prognosis.
row.field_feature_card_description: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma, or FLHCC, is a rare cancer of the liver that usually grows in teens and adults under 40 years old. It is unsusal because it occurs in people who have healthy livers.
row.field_list_description: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma, or FLHCC, is a rare cancer of the liver that usually grows in teens and adults under 40 years old. It is unsusal because it occurs in people who have healthy livers.

row.title: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Vaccines
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet about human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccines for the prevention of infection with certain types of HPV, which is the major cause of cervical cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn about HPV vaccines, which protect against infections that cause cervical cancer and several other types of cancer.

row.title: Lymphoma—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Lymphoma is cancer that begins in cells of the lymph system. The two main types are Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). Hodgkin lymphoma can often be cured. The prognosis of NHL depends on the specific type. Start here to find information about lymphoma treatment, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: Information about non-Hodgkin lymphoma and Hodgkin lymphoma treatment, clinical trials, research, statistics, and other topics from the National Cancer Institute.

row.title: Research Funding Opportunities
row.field_page_description: Find a wide range of funding announcements to support cancer research and training, organized by topic and by funding mechanism.
row.field_list_description: Find a wide range of funding announcements to support cancer research, organized by topic and alternatively by funding mechanism.

row.title: The Genetics of Cancer
row.field_page_description: Information about genetic changes, how they may be inherited or acquired during a person's life, how they can increase cancer risk, and genetic testing for mutations.
row.field_feature_card_description: Genetic changes, which may be inherited or acquired during a person's life, can increase cancer risk.
row.field_list_description: Information about genetic changes, how they may be inherited or acquired during a person's life, and how they can increase cancer risk.

row.title: Carcinoma of Unknown Primary—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Carcinoma of unknown primary (CUP) occurs when cancer cells have spread in the body and formed metastatic tumors but the site of the primary cancer is not known. There are a number of reasons why the primary cancer may not be found. Start here to find treatment information for carcinoma of unknown primary.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about Carcinoma of Unknown Primary.

row.title: Obesity
row.field_page_description: People who are obese may have an increased risk of several types of cancer, whereas eating a healthy diet, being physically active, and keeping a healthy weight may help reduce risk of some cancers.

row.title: Complementary and Alternative Medicine
row.field_page_description: Healing philosophies, approaches, and therapies used in complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) in cancer care.

row.title: Vitamin D and Cancer Prevention
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that summarizes the results of studies on vitamin D and cancer prevention. It includes information about dietary recommendations for vitamin D.
row.field_feature_card_description: A fact sheet that summarizes the results of studies on vitamin D and cancer prevention.

row.title: Study Shows Platelets Can Deliver Immunotherapy, Reduce Tumor Regrowth
row.field_short_title: Platelets Deliver Immunotherapy, Slow Tumor Growth
row.field_page_description: An NCI Cancer Currents blog on an experimental adjuvant therapy using blood platelets engineered to deliver an immune checkpoint inhibitor.
row.field_feature_card_description: In mouse studies, the treatment prevented cancer cells from growing after surgery.
row.field_list_description: In experiments in mice, researchers show platelets linked to an immunotherapy drug can help eliminate residual cancer cells that remain after surgery. The engineered platelets may also prevent leftover cancer cells from spreading.

row.title: Functional Genomics Research
row.field_page_description: NCI's Center for Cancer Genomics uses functional genomics to understand the impact of cancer genes and pathways, and how to target them effectively.
row.field_feature_card_description: Functional genomics studies the role of particular cancer genes and pathways, and develops therapeutic strategies to target them. CCG's related research includes the Cancer Target Discovery and Development Network and the Human Cancer Models Initiative.
row.field_list_description: Functional genomics studies the role of particular cancer genes and pathways, and develops therapeutic strategies to target them. CCG's functional genomics research includes the Cancer Target Discovery and Development Network and the Human Cancer Models Initiative.

row.title: Cancer Clinical Trials at the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center
row.field_short_title: Cancer Clinical Trials at the NIH Clinical Center
row.field_page_description: Information about cancer clinical trials at the NIH Clinical Center in Bethesda, Maryland.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI trials in Bethesda, Maryland, aim to solve important problems in cancer research and patient care.

row.title: Blinatumomab Extends Survival for Patients with Advanced ALL
row.field_short_title: Blinatumomab Improves Survival in Advanced ALL
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog post on a large clinical trial showing that blinatumomab improves survival and causes fewer side effects than standard chemotherapy.
row.field_feature_card_description: The immunotherapy drug also caused fewer side effects than chemotherapy.
row.field_list_description: Patients with previously treated acute lymphoblastic leukemia who received blinatumomab, which encourages the immune system to kill cancer cells, lived longer and experienced fewer side effects than patients given standard chemotherapy.

row.title: NCI Funding for HIV and AIDS Malignancies Research
row.field_short_title: NCI Funding for HIV/AIDS Malignancies Research
row.field_page_description: OHAM supports funding to advance the study of HIV/AIDS-related cancers. Find funding to investigate HIV/AIDS infection, transmission, and treatment.
row.field_feature_card_description: Explore funding opportunities to investigate infection, transmission, and treatment of HIV and HIV/AIDS-related malignancies.
row.field_list_description: Find funding for research to advance the study of HIV/AIDS-related cancers, including the application of big data and multidisciplinary studies that investigate treatment, co-infection, and aids-defining or non-aids-defining cancers.

row.title: Cancer Moonshot℠ Research Initiatives
row.field_page_description: Implementation teams are considering multiple ways to fund new programs as well as expansions of ongoing efforts to advance the goals of the Cancer Moonshot.

row.title: NCI HIV and AIDS Research Coordinated by OHAM
row.field_short_title: NCI HIV/AIDS Research Coordinated by OHAM
row.field_page_description: NCI scientists have made a number of critical contributions to HIV/AIDS research since the beginning of the AIDS epidemic. Learn more about intramural and extramural research supported by NCI.
row.field_feature_card_description: Scientists working at NCI campuses conduct an active research program in HIV/AIDS malignancies, and NCI supports extramural research focused on HIV/AIDS.
row.field_list_description: An active research program in HIV/AIDS and HIV malignancies is conducted by scientists working at the NCI campuses in Bethesda, Rockville, and Frederick, Maryland. In addition, extramural research focused on HIV malignancies is supported by the NCI.

row.title: New Rituximab Formulation Approved for Some Lymphomas, Leukemia
row.field_short_title: FDA Approves Subcutaneous Rituximab for Some Blood Cancers
row.field_page_description: An NCI Cancer Currents blog on FDA’s approval of a new formulation of rituximab, Rituxan Hycela, for some patients with lymphoma and leukemia.
row.field_feature_card_description: The drug can now be given via injection, greatly speeding up administration.
row.field_list_description: The FDA has approved a new formulation of rituximab, Rituxan Hycela, that reduces treatment administration time for patients with several types of blood cancer.

row.title: Cancer Moonshot℠ Funding Opportunities Resources
row.field_page_description: Funding opportunities that address the goals of the Blue Ribbon Panel are available. Learn more about these FOAs and pre-application webinars.

row.title: Cancer in Children and Adolescents
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet about statistics, types, causes, and treatment of childhood cancers in the United States.

row.title: Professional Resources for Cancer Patient Education
row.field_page_description: Information about the NCI listserv for cancer patient educators, and the Cancer Patient Education Network.

row.title: Tests to Detect Colorectal Cancer and Polyps
row.field_short_title: Tests to Detect Colorectal Cancer and Polyps
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that discusses the advantages and disadvantages of several colorectal cancer screening tests.
row.field_feature_card_description: This fact sheet discusses the advantages and disadvantages of several colorectal cancer screening tests.

row.title: Leukemia—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Leukemia is a broad term for cancers of the blood cells. The type of leukemia depends on the type of blood cell that becomes cancer and whether it grows quickly or slowly. Start here to find information on leukemia treatment, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: Information about leukemia treatment, clinical trials, research, statistics, and other topics.

row.title: Garlic and Cancer Prevention
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that summarizes the results of studies on the consumption of garlic for cancer prevention.

row.title: Radon and Cancer
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet about radon, an odorless radioactive gas, and its possible association with cancer, and how to test for radon in the home.
row.field_feature_card_description: A fact sheet about radon, an odorless radioactive gas, and its possible association with cancer, and how to test for radon in the home.

row.title: Long-Term Trial Results Show No Mortality Benefit from Annual Prostate Cancer Screening
row.field_short_title: Long-Term Trial Results Show No Mortality Benefit from Annual Prostate Cancer Screening
row.field_page_description: Thirteen year follow-up data from the Prostate, Lung, Colorectal and Ovarian (PLCO) cancer screening trial show higher incidence but similar mortality among men screened annually with the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test and digital rectal examination
row.field_feature_card_description: Thirteen year follow-up data from the Prostate, Lung, Colorectal and Ovarian (PLCO) cancer screening trial show higher incidence but similar mortality among men screened annually with the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test and digital rectal examination
row.field_list_description: Thirteen year follow-up data from the Prostate, Lung, Colorectal and Ovarian (PLCO) cancer screening trial show higher incidence but similar mortality among men screened annually with the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test and digital rectal examination (DRE).

row.title: FDA Approves New Use for Lenalidomide in Multiple Myeloma
row.field_short_title: FDA Approves New Use for Lenalidomide in Multiple Myeloma
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog on the approval of lenalidomide as maintenance therapy for patients with multiple myeloma who have received an autologous stem cell transplant.
row.field_feature_card_description: Drug approved as maintenance therapy after a stem cell transplant.
row.field_list_description: The FDA has approved lenalidomide for use as a maintenance therapy in patients with multiple myeloma who have undergone an autologous stem cell transplant, to help keep the cancer from coming back.

row.title: Stem-Cell Based Tool May Help Measure Heart Toxicity of Cancer Drugs
row.field_short_title: Stem Cell-Based Tool Ranks Heart Toxicity of Cancer Drugs
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog post on a new research study that uses a type of adult stem cell to assess the heart toxicity of cancer drugs known as tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
row.field_feature_card_description: The "cardiac safety index" may help identify drugs that cause side effects earlier in the drug development process.
row.field_list_description: Researchers have used adult stem cells to create a tool for ranking how toxic a group of cancer drugs, called tyrosine kinase inhibitors, are to human heart cells. Such a test could potentially identify toxic side effects earlier in the drug development process.

row.title: Office of HIV and AIDS Malignancy
row.field_short_title: Office of HIV and AIDS Malignancy
row.field_page_description: OHAM conducts HIV and AIDS-associated research and coordinates related research activities across NCI. Learn more about key discoveries made by NCI scientists.
row.field_feature_card_description: OHAM conducts HIV and AIDS-associated research and coordinates related research activities across NCI.
row.field_list_description: OHAM conducts HIV and AIDS-associated research and coordinates related research activities across NCI. OHAM includes two programs, the AIDS Malignancy Program and the AIDS Cancer Clinical Program.

row.title: AIDS Malignancy Consortium
row.field_page_description: AMC was founded in 1995 to support trial innovation. Learn more about AMC’s commitment to enhancing therapeutic options for patients with HIV-associated malignancies.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn more about AMC’s commitment to supporting innovation in clinical trials.
row.field_list_description: The AIDS Malignancy Consortium is an NCI-supported clinical trials group founded in 1995 to support trial innovation. Learn more about this group of clinical centers committed to enhancing therapeutic options for patients with HIV-associated malignancies.

row.title: Program Spotlight: Training Navigation
row.field_page_description: Dr. Hana Odeh talks about CRCHD’s new training navigation initiative and her role as training navigator.
row.field_feature_card_description: Dr. Hana Odeh talks about CRCHD’s new training navigation initiative and her role as training navigator.
row.field_list_description: Dr. Hana Odeh talks about CRCHD’s new training navigation initiative and her role as training navigator.

row.title: In an Era of Precision Medicine, Testing New Approaches to Breast Cancer Screening
row.field_short_title: Testing Precision Screening for Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: An NCI research article about individualized approaches that could help identify those at risk of breast cancer who need to be screened and testing screening intervals that are appropriate for each person’s level of risk.
row.field_feature_card_description: Identifying appropriate screening tests and screening intervals for each person’s level of risk.
row.field_list_description: Researchers are testing individualized approaches that could identify those at risk of breast cancer who need to be screened and testing screening intervals that are appropriate for each person’s level of risk.

row.title: Advancing the Potential and Promise of Total-Body PET Imaging
row.field_short_title: Advancing the Promise of Total-Body PET Imaging
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog on how NCI is supporting a total-body PET scanner and the institute’s role in advancing new research and cancer care-related technologies.
row.field_feature_card_description: Still under development, scanner could fundamentally alter cancer care.
row.field_list_description: A total-body PET scanner under development is an ideal example of how NCI and NIH are supporting the development of new research and cancer care-related technologies.

row.title: April Spotlight: National Minority Health Month
row.field_short_title: April Spotlight: National Minority Health Month
row.field_page_description: Each April, we recognize National Minority Health Month and National Minority Cancer Awareness Week. Dr. Peter Ogunbiyi shares how CRCHD’s work is related to the 2017 theme: Bridging Health Equity Across Communities.
row.field_feature_card_description: Each April, we recognize National Minority Health Month and National Minority Cancer Awareness Week.

row.title: Clinical Trial Sequencing Project
row.field_page_description: The Clinical Trial Sequencing Project performs genomic characterization of samples from NCI-sponsored trials with the goal of improving the understanding and treatment of various cancers.

row.title: Tumor Metastasis Research
row.field_page_description: Tumor metastasis research examines the mechanisms that allow cancer cells to leave the primary tumor and spread to another part of the body. Learn about recent tumor metastasis research studies supported by the Division of Cancer Biology.
row.field_feature_card_description: A research area that defines the mechanisms of tumor metastasis which allow tumor cells to leave the primary tumor, survive and travel through the circulation or lymph and ultimately enter distant tissues and expand.
row.field_list_description: A research area that defines the mechanisms of tumor metastasis which allow tumor cells to leave the primary tumor, survive and travel through the circulation or lymph and ultimately enter distant tissues and expand.

row.title: Nanoparticles Create Effective CAR T Cells in Living Mice
row.field_short_title: Nanoparticles Create Effective CAR T Cells in Mice
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog on the development of a method to genetically engineer cancer-fighting immune cells, known as CAR T cells, in living animals using nanoparticles that carry DNA.
row.field_feature_card_description: Engineered immune cells eliminated leukemia in the animals.
row.field_list_description: Researchers have developed a method to genetically engineer cancer-fighting immune cells in living animals using nanoparticles that carry DNA. The new study shows that the resulting immune cells, known as CAR T cells, eliminated leukemia in mice.

row.title: Cancer Risk - Cancer Currents Blog
row.field_page_description: Blog posts on research related to cancer risk—including inherited, behavioral, and environmental risks and studies about decreasing risk—from NCI Cancer Currents.
row.field_feature_card_description: Cancer risk-related blog posts from NCI Cancer Currents.
row.field_list_description: Blog posts on research related to cancer risk—including inherited, behavioral, and environmental risks and studies about decreasing risk—from NCI Cancer Currents.

row.title: FDA Approvals - Cancer Currents Blog
row.field_page_description: Blog posts on cancer drugs and devices approved by the Food and Drug Administration—including summaries of the evidence to support the approvals and what they mean for patients—from NCI Cancer Currents.
row.field_feature_card_description: Summaries of FDA approvals of cancer drugs and devices from NCI Cancer Currents.

row.title: Copanlisib Approved for Follicular Lymphoma
row.field_page_description: Copanlisib (Aliqopa®), a type of PI3K inhibitor, has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of patients with advanced follicular lymphoma.
row.field_feature_card_description: Now second PI3K inhibitor approved for patients with advanced follicular lymphoma.
row.field_list_description: FDA has granted accelerated approval to copanlisib (Aliqopa®) for the treatment of patients with follicular lymphoma, a form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

row.title: Study Uses Open Data to Analyze “Normal” Tissue Near Tumors
row.field_short_title: Tissue adjacent to tumors may not be “normal,” study finds
row.field_page_description: The tissue immediately surrounding a tumor may not be normal, even if it appears normal under the microscope, as this Cancer Currents article explains.
row.field_feature_card_description: Findings suggest extensive tumor interaction with surrounding tissue.
row.field_list_description: The tissue immediately surrounding a tumor may not be normal, even if it appears normal under the microscope, according to an analysis of data from two genomic databases.

row.title: Expanding Smoking Cessation Services at NCI-Designated Cancer Centers: An Interview with Dr. Glen Morgan
row.field_short_title: Expanding Smoking Cessation at NCI-Designated Cancer Centers
row.field_page_description: A new smoking cessation initiative will support NCI-Designated Cancer Centers efforts to help more patients quit smoking, as Dr. Glen Morgan explains in this Cancer Currents interview.
row.field_feature_card_description: Initiative is aimed at helping cancer patients to stop smoking.
row.field_list_description: NCI’s Dr. Glen Morgan discusses NCI’s Cancer Center Cessation Initiative, including how and why this smoking cessation initiative was developed and its long-term goals.

row.title: Acalabrutinib Receives FDA Approval for Mantle Cell Lymphoma
row.field_short_title: Acalabrutinib Approved for Mantle Cell Lymphoma
row.field_page_description: Acalabrutinib (Calquence®) has been granted accelerated approval by FDA for the treatment of adults with mantle cell lymphoma whose cancer has progressed after receiving at least one prior therapy.
row.field_feature_card_description: Approval based on promising results in early phase clinical trial.
row.field_list_description: The FDA has granted accelerated approval to acalabrutinib (Calquence®) for the treatment of adults with mantle cell lymphoma whose cancer has progressed after receiving at least one prior therapy.

row.title: Selected Publications by the NCI Director
row.field_short_title: Selected Publications by the NCI Director
row.field_page_description: Dr. Norman Sharpless's written work on cancer research appears in many leading scientific journals, as well as a variety of other publications. This page lists some of the articles published by Dr. Sharpless since becoming NCI director.

row.title: Strengthening CGH’s partnerships in cancer research and control in Africa: AORTIC 2017
row.field_short_title: Strengthening CGH’s partnerships in cancer research and control in Africa: AORTIC 2017

row.title: Selected Interviews with the NCI Director
row.field_short_title: Selected Interviews by the NCI Director
row.field_page_description: See interviews given by Dr. Norman “Ned” Sharpless during his time as NCI director.
row.field_feature_card_description: The National Cancer Institute director is frequently interviewed by media, scientific, and nonprofit organizations about a variety of topics of interest to the cancer community.
row.field_list_description: The National Cancer Institute director is frequently interviewed by media, scientific, and nonprofit organizations about a variety of topics of interest to the cancer community. See interviews given by Dr. Norman "Ned" Sharpless during his time as NCI director.

row.title: Hexavalent Chromium Compounds
row.field_page_description: Learn about chromium, exposure to which can increase your risk of lung cancer and cancer of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity. Hexavalent chromium compounds have been used as corrosion inhibitors in a wide variety of products and processes.

row.title: Benzene
row.field_page_description: Learn about benzene, a component of crude oil and other substances. Exposure to benzene may increase the risk of leukemia and other blood disorders. Among smokers, 90 percent of benzene exposure comes from smoking. Benzene may also be found in glues, adhesives, and paint or cleaning products.

row.title: Beryllium
row.field_page_description: Learn about beryllium, exposure to which can increase your risk of lung cancer. Beryllium is a naturally occurring, light-weight metal used in products such as aerospace components, transistors, nuclear reactors, and golf clubs. Most exposures occur to workers who produce such products.

row.title: Coal Tar and Coal-Tar Pitch
row.field_page_description: Learn about coal-tar products, which can raise your risk of skin cancer, lung cancer, and other types of cancer. Examples of coal-tar products include creosote, coal-tar pitch, and certain preparations used to treat skin conditions such as eczema, psoriasis, and dandruff.

row.title: Crystalline Silica
row.field_page_description: Learn about crystalline silica (quartz dust), which can raise your risk of lung cancer. Crystalline silica is present in certain construction materials such as concrete, masonry, and brick and also in commercial products such as some cleansers, cosmetics, pet litter, talcum powder, caulk, and paint.

row.title: Global Prostate Cancer Disparities in Black Men
row.field_short_title: Global Prostate Cancer Disparities in Black Men
row.field_page_description: Global Prostate Cancer Disparities in Black Men

row.title: Combining Two Types of Targeted Therapy Improves Survival in Some Patients with Advanced Melanoma (Updated)
row.field_short_title: Dabrafenib Plus Trametinib for Advanced Melanoma
row.field_page_description: A summary of results from two phase III trials show that patients with metastatic melanoma whose tumors have specific mutations in the BRAF gene lived longer following treatment with dabrafenib (Tafinlar®), a BRAF inhibitor, plus trametinib (Mekinist®), a
row.field_feature_card_description: In two phase III trials, patients with metastatic melanoma whose tumors have specific mutations in the BRAF gene lived longer following treatment with dabrafenib (Tafinlar®), a BRAF inhibitor, plus trametinib (Mekinist®), a MEK inhibitor, than following t
row.field_list_description: In two phase III trials, patients with metastatic melanoma whose tumors have specific mutations in the BRAF gene lived longer following treatment with dabrafenib (Tafinlar®), a BRAF inhibitor, plus trametinib (Mekinist®), a MEK inhibitor, than following treatment with a BRAF inhibitor alone.

row.title: FDA Approves Ribociclib, Expands Palbociclib Approval for Metastatic Breast Cancer
row.field_short_title: FDA Approves Ribociclib, Palbociclib for Metastatic Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog on the FDA’s approval of two targeted therapies, ribociclib and palbociclib, for women with metastatic breast cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Two targeted therapies are approved for use with an aromatase inhibitor.
row.field_list_description: The FDA has approved a new targeted therapy, ribociclib, and expanded its earlier approval of another targeted therapy, palbociclib, for some women with metastatic breast cancer.

row.title: Collection of Patient-Reported Outcomes Feasible in Cancer Clinical Trials
row.field_short_title: Collecting Patient-Reported Outcomes in Cancer Clinical Trials
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog post on a study showing that patient-reported outcomes, or PROs, can be successfully collected during cancer clinical trials
row.field_feature_card_description: Patient-reported outcomes may help clarify how new drugs affect quality of life.
row.field_list_description: Cancer patients, even those who are undergoing difficult treatments, are willing to devote time to completing thorough assessments of the side effects they encounter in clinical trials, a new study finds.

row.title: NCI ALMANAC: A New Tool for Research on Cancer Drug Combinations
row.field_short_title: NCI ALMANAC Tool for Research on Cancer Drug Combinations
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog post on the NCI ALMANAC, a new resource that provides data showing how well pairs of FDA-approved cancer drugs performed in killing tumor cells from NCI-60 Human Tumor Cell Lines.
row.field_feature_card_description: The resource provides data showing how well pairs of FDA-approved drugs kill tumor cells.
row.field_list_description: NCI has released a new, easy-to-use resource called the NCI ALMANAC to help researchers identify potentially promising combinations of cancer drugs.

row.title: Prevention - Cancer Currents Blog
row.field_page_description: Blog posts on cancer prevention research—including behavioral interventions and other ways to prevent cancer and prevention-related research programs—from NCI Cancer Currents.
row.field_feature_card_description: Cancer prevention-related blog posts from NCI Cancer Currents.

row.title: April Spotlight: National Minority Health Month
row.field_short_title: April Spotlight: National Minority Health Month
row.field_page_description: Each April, we recognize National Minority Health Month (NMHM) because of its direct relevance to us at the National Cancer Institute’s Center to Reduce Cancer Health Disparities (NCI CRCHD). This year’s NMHM theme, Partnering for Health Equity, brings attention to the need for individuals, institutions, and communitie
row.field_feature_card_description: Each April, we recognize National Minority Health Month (NMHM). This year’s theme is Partnering for Health Equity.

row.title: A Conversation About RAS Dimers
row.field_page_description: RAS proteins seem to be dimeric in living cells, but monomeric in vitro. Understanding RAS dimers may be important for finding treatments for RAS cancers.
row.field_feature_card_description: Understanding RAS dimers may enable treatments for RAS cancers.
row.field_list_description: Data are persuasive that RAS proteins are dimeric in living cells, but monomeric in vitro. Pasi Jänne, Chiara Ambrogio, and Frank McCormick discuss the significance of understanding RAS dimers for finding treatments for RAS cancers.

row.title: Moving Beyond BMI: Low Muscle Mass May Affect Cancer Survival
row.field_short_title: Low Muscle Mass Linked with Worse Cancer Survival
row.field_page_description: In a new study, researchers compared the risk of death for women with breast cancer who had low skeletal muscle mass, or sarcopenia, at diagnosis and women who had adequate muscle mass. Learn what they found and what it might mean for patients in this Cancer Currents blog post.
row.field_feature_card_description: A high percentage of women had the condition at time of diagnosis.
row.field_list_description: Researchers compared the risk of death for women with breast cancer who had low skeletal muscle mass, or sarcopenia, at the time of their cancer diagnosis and women who had adequate muscle mass.

row.title: Immunotherapy Drugs Expand Treatment Options for Advanced Lung Cancer
row.field_short_title: Immunotherapy Expands Lung Cancer Treatment Options
row.field_page_description: Results from a large clinical trial show combining the immune checkpoint inhibitor pembrolizumab (Keytruda) with chemotherapy helped some patients with advanced cancer live longer. As this Cancer Currents post explains, the results will immediately affect patient care.
row.field_feature_card_description: Results of a large clinical trial will immediately affect patient care.
row.field_list_description: Results from a large clinical trial show combining an immune checkpoint inhibitor with chemotherapy helped some patients with advanced lung cancer live longer than chemotherapy alone. How will this change the lung cancer treatment landscape?

row.title: Vaginal Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: Find research articles on vaginal cancer, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.

row.title: Gene Therapy Approach for Ovarian Cancer Shows Encouraging Signs in Animal Model
row.field_short_title: Gene Therapy in Mouse Model of Ovarian Cancer
row.field_page_description: A single injection of a gene therapy viral vector inhibited tumor growth of some mouse tumors derived from patients with recurrent ovarian cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: A gene therapy approach blocked tumor growth in mice with ovarian cancer.

row.title: DCB Funding
row.field_page_description: The Division of Cancer Biology (DCB) funds and supports extramural basic research that investigates the fundamental biology behind cancer. Find out more about DCB's grants process and funding opportunities.
row.field_feature_card_description: Find out more about DCB's grants process and funding opportunities.
row.field_list_description: The Division of Cancer Biology funds and supports extramural basic research that investigates the fundamental biology behind cancer. Find out more about DCB's grants process and funding opportunities.

row.title: New Planning Grant Announced Promotes NCD Research
row.field_short_title: New Planning Grant Announced Promotes NCD Research
row.field_page_description: NCI launches the Regional Centers of Research Excellence (RCRE) program.

row.title: Cancer Trends: Influencing Care and Research Priorities
row.field_short_title: Cancer Trends: Influencing Care and Research Priorities
row.field_page_description: Many of the trends being seen in cancer are changing how we view cancer and how we address it, from prompting research to identify the underlying causes of cancers increasing in incidence to informing research on treatment and prevention.
row.field_feature_card_description: SEER, NCI’s chief means of monitoring key trends, is being enhanced to better serve research needs.

row.title: Bringing Precision to Screening for Cancer
row.field_short_title: Bringing Precision to Screening for Cancer
row.field_page_description: A recent NCI-sponsored conference brought together leading screening and cancer control researchers to discuss the state of the science of precision screening for five cancers.
row.field_feature_card_description: Researchers seek better ways to determine who will benefit from regular cancer screening.

row.title: Cancer Informatics: Expanding Access to Cancer Genomics Data
row.field_page_description: The NCI Genomic Data Commons and Cloud Pilots expand access to cancer genomics data by compiling and harmonzed data into a central data repository.
row.field_feature_card_description: Genomic Data Commons and Cloud Pilots Expand Access to Data
row.field_list_description: Drs. Staudt and Kibbe discuss the NCI’s major initiatives to improve both the accessibility and usability of cancer genomics data. Top among the NCI’s priorities are the Genomic Data Commons, a service that will bring together and harmonize cancer genomic data sets from NCI programs and non-NCI data submitters, and the Cancer Genomics Cloud Pilots.

row.title: What an Indian Proverb Can Teach Us About Communication
row.field_short_title: What an Indian Proverb Can Teach Us About Communication
row.field_page_description: Cancer Research in the Media: International Workshop for Scientific Journalism (CRiM), held last month in India - a partnership of the NCI Office of Communications and Public Liaison (OCPL) and NCI Center for Global Health (CGH).

row.title: A Conversation with Allan Balmain
row.field_page_description: Dr. Allan Balmain talks about his career path as a pioneer in RAS biology.

row.title: Drugs Approved for Conditions Related to Cancer
row.field_short_title: Drugs Approved for Conditions Related to Cancer
row.field_page_description: People with cancer may have other conditions caused by the cancer or its treatment. Drugs approved by the FDA for some of these cancer-related conditions are listed on this page, and link to NCI's Cancer Drug Information Summaries.
row.field_list_description: Conditions related to cancer are listed with links to information about drugs used in those conditions. The drug names link to NCI's Cancer Drug Information summaries.

row.title: Diarrhea and Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Diarrhea, a side effect of cancer treatment, may cause symptoms such as loose, watery stools. Diarrhea can lead to dehydration and malnutrition in cancer patients. Learn about ways to treat and manage diarrhea during cancer treatment.
row.field_list_description: Information about what causes diarrhea, a side effect of cancer treatment, and ways to manage it. Symptoms and treatments to manage diarrhea are also explained for cancer patients.

row.title: NCI’s Role in Cancer Research
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI supports and advances cancer research in many ways.

row.title: Bringing the Investigational Breast Cancer Drug Endoxifen from Bench to Bedside with NCI Support
row.field_short_title: Bringing Endoxifen from Bench to Bedside
row.field_page_description: Endoxifen, a breast cancer drug being tested in clinical trials, had critical support from NCI, the Mayo Clinic’s Dr. Matthew Goetz writes in this Cancer Currents blog post.
row.field_feature_card_description: Early-phase clinical trials of endoxifen show promising results.
row.field_list_description: Researchers recognized the potential of endoxifen as a treatment for breast cancer and, with NCI support, developed the compound into a drug now being tested in clinical trials.

row.title: Forgoing Conventional Cancer Treatments for Alternative Medicine Increases Risk of Death
row.field_short_title: Alternative Medicine for Cancer Treatment Raises Mortality Risk
row.field_page_description: Choosing alternative medicine as an initial cancer treatment led to substantially worse survival than patients who received conventional cancer treatments, this Cancer Currents post explains.
row.field_feature_card_description: Survival much lower in patients choosing alternative therapies over conventional treatments.
row.field_list_description: In a large study, patients with nonmetastatic breast, lung, or colorectal cancer who chose alternative therapies had substantially worse survival than patients who received conventional cancer treatments.

row.title: A Brief Tour of DAVE: The Genomic Data Commons Analysis Toolkit
row.field_page_description: Get a tour of GDC's genomic analysis and visualization tools
row.field_feature_card_description: Get a tour of GDC's DAVE: Data Analysis, Visualization & Exploration Tools
row.field_list_description: The Genomic Data Commons (GDC) gives a brief tour of DAVE: Data Analysis, Visualization, and Exploration Tools. GDC welcomes user questions and feedback to help build an accessible and valuable genomic data resource.

row.title: Pembrolizumab Secures FDA Approval in Stomach Cancer
row.field_short_title: Pembrolizumab Secures FDA Approval in Stomach Cancer
row.field_page_description: FDA has approved the immunotherapy drug pembrolizumab (Keytruda®) for use in some patients with advanced gastric (stomach) cancer that is PD-L1 positive.
row.field_feature_card_description: Approval is for some patients with advanced cancer that is PD-L1 positive.
row.field_list_description: The FDA has granted accelerated approval to the immunotherapy drug pembrolizumab (Keytruda®) for use in patients with advanced gastric (stomach) cancer that is PD-L1 positive.

row.title: Abemaciclib Approved by FDA for Advanced or Metastatic Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: Abemaciclib (Verzenio™), a type of CDK4/6 inhibitor, has been approved by FDA for some patients with advanced or metastatic breast cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Approval is for some patients with advanced or metastatic breast cancer.
row.field_list_description: FDA approved abemaciclib (Verzenio™) for the treatment of some people with advanced or metastatic HR-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer whose disease has progressed after treatment with hormone therapy.

row.title: Questions to Ask Your Doctor about Your Treatment
row.field_short_title: Questions to Ask about Your Treatment
row.field_page_description: Suggested questions for cancer patients to ask their doctors about treatment choices and the possible side effects of cancer treatment.
row.field_feature_card_description: Suggested questions to ask your doctor about treatment choices and the possible side effects of treatment.
row.field_list_description: Suggested questions to ask your doctor about treatment choices and the possible side effects of cancer treatment.

row.title: Thoracic Malignancy Steering Committee Roster
A Message from Dr. Frank McCormick
row.field_short_title: A Message from Dr. Frank McCormick
row.field_page_description: Frank McCormick, pioneering RAS researcher and former head of the UCSF cancer center, describes the problem with RAS cancers and how the NCI RAS Initiative will attack them.

row.title: NCI Outstanding Investigator Award (R35) Frequently Asked Questions
row.field_page_description: Frequently asked questions for the NCI Outstanding Investigator Award.
row.field_feature_card_description: Frequently asked questions for the NCI Outstanding Investigator Award.

row.title: Contact the Office of Budget and Finance
row.field_page_description: Address and phone number for NCI's Office of Budget and Finance.

row.title: RAS Structural Biology
row.field_page_description: The RAS Structural Biology group determines the structures of RAS proteins, alone and in complex with important effectors.
row.field_feature_card_description: This group aims to provide structural insights into oncogenic mutants of RAS, RAS-effector, and RAS-interactor complexes.
row.field_list_description: This group aims to provide structural insights into oncogenic mutants of RAS, RAS-effector, and RAS-interactor complexes.

row.title: Microbes within Our Bodies May Cause or Contribute to Cancer
row.field_short_title: Microbes within Our Bodies May Cause or Contribute to Cancer

row.title: Christal Sohl, Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: The San Diego State University biologist uses a variety of methods, including structural, computational, and kinetic analyses, to study enzymes that may play a role in cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: The San Diego State University biologist studies enzymes that may play a role in cancer.

row.title: The NCI Predoctoral to Postdoctoral Fellow Transition Award (F99/K00)
row.field_short_title: The NCI Predoctoral to Postdoctoral Fellow Transition Award (F99/K00)
row.field_page_description: Apply for the NCI F99/K00 Award that helps late-stage doctoral candidates finish their training and then transition into cancer-focused research positions.

row.title: Olaparib Approved for Treating Some Breast Cancers with BRCA Gene Mutations
row.field_short_title: Olaparib Approved for Breast Cancers with BRCA Gene Mutations
row.field_page_description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved olaparib (Lynparza®) to treat metastatic breast cancers that have inherited mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes as well as a companion diagnostic test for selecting candidates for the therapy.
row.field_feature_card_description: In the trial that led to approval, the drug caused fewer side effects than standard chemotherapy.
row.field_list_description: The drug olaparib (Lynparza®) is the first treatment approved by the Food and Drug Administration for patients with metastatic breast cancer who have inherited mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes.

row.title: For Rare Melanoma, Checkpoint Inhibitors May Hold Substantial Promise
row.field_short_title: Checkpoint Inhibitors Hold Promise for Rare Melanoma
row.field_page_description: Patients with a rare form of melanoma, called desmoplastic melanoma, may be particularly likely to benefit from immune checkpoint inhibitors, a new study shows. As this Cancer Currents post explains, an NCI-sponsored clinical trial is already testing one such drug, pembrolizumab (Keytruda) in patients with this cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Patients with desmoplastic melanoma may be particularly likely to benefit.
row.field_list_description: A new study suggests that patients with a rare form of melanoma, called desmoplastic melanoma, may be particularly likely to benefit from treatments known as immune checkpoint inhibitors. An NCI-sponsored clinical trial is already testing one such drug in patients with this cancer.

row.title: Clinical Trials for Childhood Brain Stem Glioma
row.field_short_title: Clinical Trials for Childhood Brain Stem Glioma

row.title: Drug May Help Prevent Resistance to Toxin-Based Leukemia Therapy
row.field_short_title: Drug May Help Prevent Resistance to Toxin-Based Leukemia Therapy
row.field_page_description: Adding the drug 5-AZA to moxetumomab pasudotox, a toxin-based cancer drug, may improve its efficacy in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). As this Cancer Currents blog post explains, in mice, both drugs were more effective than moxetumomab alone.
row.field_feature_card_description: In mice, giving 5-AZA along with moxetumomab improved its efficacy.
row.field_list_description: A new study has identified a possible strategy for improving the efficacy of a toxin-based cancer treatment, moxetumomab pasudotox, in some patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

row.title: Assessing the International Landscape of Cancer Research through Successful Partnership
row.field_page_description: On April 11th, 2018 the NCI Center for Research Strategy, in coordination with CGH, hosted the Annual Meeting of the International Cancer Research Partnership (ICRP). The meeting marked 18 years of a successful partnership, representing 124 organizations that fund cancer research projects in 145 countries.

row.title: Get Involved: Community Groups for Trainees and Fellows
row.field_page_description: Cancer research fellows and trainees will find information about special interest groups at NCI and NIH. Learn more about how to get involved.
row.field_feature_card_description: Trainees will find information and resources to support their NCI fellowship.
row.field_list_description: Learn about community groups, committees, and leadership opportunities at NCI and NIH.

row.title: New to NCI: Information for New Trainees and Fellows
row.field_short_title: New to NCI: Information for New Trainees
row.field_page_description: Fellows and cancer research trainees will find information to support their onboarding at NCI, including stipend and tax information and NIH rules and regulations. Learn more about orientation for NCI trainees.
row.field_feature_card_description: Trainees will find information to support their onboarding experience.
row.field_list_description: Find information to support onboarding at NCI, including stipend and tax information and NIH rules and regulations.

row.title: Screening Tests
row.field_page_description: Information about tests such as mammography and colonoscopy that may be used to screen for cancer in people without symptoms of disease.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information about cancer screening and the types of tests used to find cancer.
row.field_list_description: Information about tests that may be used to screen for cancer in people without symptoms of disease.

row.title: Overcoming the Challenges of Metastatic Cancer: An Interview with Dr. Rosandra Kaplan
row.field_short_title: Overcoming the Challenges of Metastatic Cancer
row.field_page_description: NCI’s Dr. Rosandra Kaplan discusses metastatic cancer research and new ideas for treating and preventing metastatic cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI’s Dr. Rosandra Kaplan on important trends in metastatic cancer research.
row.field_list_description: NCI’s Dr. Rosandra Kaplan discusses important trends in metastatic cancer research and new ideas for treating and preventing metastatic cancer.

row.title: Kids First Pediatric Research Program Moves Forward
row.field_short_title: Kids First Pediatric Research Program Moves Forward
row.field_page_description: A new data resource center is being developed for the Gabriella Miller Kids First Research Program, so investigators can better collaborate on childhood cancers and birth defect research.
row.field_feature_card_description: Researchers developing central resource for data sharing.
row.field_list_description: Progress continues to be made with the Gabriella Miller Kids First Research Program, which is creating opportunities for investigators from different research communities to share resources and collaborate on research into childhood cancers and certain birth defects.

row.title: Identifying Strategic Scientific Opportunities at NCI
row.field_page_description: As NCI's central scientific strategy office, CRS collaborates with the institute's divisions, offices, and centers to identify research opportunities to advance NCI's vision for the future of cancer research.
row.field_feature_card_description: CRS collaborates with NCI's DOCs to identify research opportunities to advance NCI's vision for hte future of cancer research.

row.title: Susan Perkins, Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: Read more about Cancer Training Branch Deputy Chief Susan Perkins, Ph.D.
row.field_list_description: Biography of Susan Perkins, Ph.D.

row.title: Dr. Levi Garraway to Deliver NCI CURE Distinguished Scholars Seminar
row.field_short_title: Dr. Levi Garraway to Deliver NCI CURE Distinguished Scholars Seminar
row.field_page_description: On July 24, 2018, Dr. Levi Garraway will deliver the next CURE Distinguished Scholars Seminar. Dr. Garraway will present on the Molecular and Genomic Characterization of Human Solid Tumors.

row.title: Selumetinib Continues to Show Promise in Children with NF1
row.field_short_title: Selumetinib Shrinks Tumors in Children with NF1
row.field_page_description: The investigational drug selumetinib shrank tumors in some children with a genetic syndrome called neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). As this Cancer Currents post explains, the drug also improved symptoms related to tumors known as neurofibromas, which can cause pain, difficulty breathing or walking, and disfigurement.
row.field_feature_card_description: The tumors can cause pain, difficulty breathing or walking, and disfigurement.
row.field_list_description: In a phase 2 clinical trial, the investigational drug selumetinib shrank tumors in some children with the genetic syndrome neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The tumors, called neurofibromas, can cause pain, difficulty breathing or walking, and disfigurement.

row.title: Respondent Burden
row.field_page_description: The respondent burden for those participating in Intramural Continuing Umbrella of Research Experiences (iCURE).
row.field_feature_card_description: iCure Respondent Burden

row.title: The Cancer Genome Atlas Program
row.field_page_description: The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) is a landmark cancer genomics program that sequenced and molecularly characterized over 11,000 cases of primary cancer samples. Learn more about how the program transformed the cancer research community and beyond.

row.title: Approval Expanded for Venetoclax in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
row.field_short_title: Approval Expanded for Venetoclax in Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
row.field_page_description: FDA expanded the approval of venetoclax (Venclexta) for people with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to include those whose cancer has progressed after previous treatment, regardless of whether their cancer cells have the deletion 17p gene alteration.
row.field_feature_card_description: Approval now includes patients without the deletion 17p gene alteration.
row.field_list_description: FDA expanded the approval of venetoclax (Venclexta) for people with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to include those whose cancer has progressed after previous treatment, regardless of whether their cancer cells have the deletion 17p gene alteration.

row.title: TCGA Computational Tools
row.field_page_description: Some of the data processing, visualization, and other computational tools developed by TCGA network researchers and collaborators.
row.field_feature_card_description: Some of the tools developed by TCGA network researchers and collaborators

row.title: Selected NCI-Supported Trials
row.field_page_description: Information about selected NCI-supported clinical trials, open or closed to patient enrollment.
row.field_feature_card_description: This page describes some of the major clinical trials that NCI supports to test promising cancer treatments and screening methods.
row.field_list_description: This page describes some of the major clinical trials that NCI supports to test promising cancer treatments and screening methods.

row.title: Site Map
row.field_page_description: Site map for the National Cancer Institute website.
row.field_list_description: Site map for the National Cancer Institute website (www.cancer.gov).

row.title: Bladder Cancer—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: The most common type of bladder cancer is transitional cell carcinoma, also called urothelial carcinoma. Smoking is a major risk factor for bladder cancer. Bladder cancer is often diagnosed at an early stage. Start here to find information on bladder cancer treatment, screening, research, and statistics.
row.field_feature_card_description: Our evidence-based information covers treatment, causes, screening, and more.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about Bladder Cancer.

row.title: Drugs Approved for Lung Cancer
row.field_page_description: This page lists cancer drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for lung cancer. The list includes generic names, brand names, and common drug combinations, which are shown in capital letters.

row.title: Drugs Approved for Kidney (Renal Cell) Cancer
row.field_short_title: Drugs Approved for Kidney (Renal Cell) Cancer
row.field_page_description: This page lists cancer drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for kidney (renal cell) cancer. The list includes generic names and brand names.

row.title: Drugs Approved for Pancreatic Cancer
row.field_page_description: This page lists cancer drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for pancreatic cancer. The list includes generic names, brand names, and common drug combinations, which are shown in capital letters.

row.title: Sallie Rosen Kaplan (SRK) Postdoctoral Fellowship for Women Scientists
row.field_page_description: The SRK Fellowship is a highly competitive, unpaid, and annual, one-year program that provides additional mentoring opportunities, networking, seminars, and workshops to help prepare NCI’s female postdoctoral fellows for the competitive nature of the job market and help them remain in a biomedical research career.

row.title: Paul Calabresi Career Development Award for Clinical Oncology (K12)
row.field_page_description: Institutional award for postdoctoral candidates or mentored junior faculty who are clinical scientists pursuing careers in patient-oriented research.
row.field_feature_card_description: Institutional award for postdoctoral candidates or mentored junior faculty who are clinical scientists pursuing careers in patient-oriented research.

row.title: Cancer Prevention, Control, Behavioral Sciences, and Population Sciences Career Development Award (K07)
row.field_page_description: For postdoctoral candidates or mentored junior faculty who are pursuing careers in cancer prevention, control, behavioral, and population sciences.

row.title: When Combined with Chemotherapy, Bevacizumab Is Associated with Increased Risk of Death
row.field_short_title: When Combined with Chemotherapy, Bevacizumab Is Associated with Increased Risk of Death
row.field_page_description: Cancer patients who receive the targeted therapy bevacizumab (Avastin) in combination with chemotherapy are at increased risk of serious side effects that may lead to death, according to a meta-analysis of 16 clinical trials that was published February 2,
row.field_feature_card_description: Cancer patients who receive the targeted therapy bevacizumab (Avastin) in combination with chemotherapy are at increased risk of serious side effects that may lead to death, according to a meta-analysis of 16 clinical trials that was published February 2,
row.field_list_description: Cancer patients who receive the targeted therapy bevacizumab (Avastin) in combination with chemotherapy are at increased risk of serious side effects that may lead to death, according to a meta-analysis of 16 clinical trials that was published February 2, 2011, in JAMA.

row.title: PSA Velocity Does Not Improve Prostate Cancer Detection
row.field_short_title: PSA Velocity Does Not Improve Prostate Cancer Detection
row.field_page_description: A rapid increase in prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels is not grounds for automatically recommending a prostate biopsy, according to a study published online February 24, 2011, in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute.
row.field_feature_card_description: A rapid increase in prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels is not grounds for automatically recommending a prostate biopsy, according to a study published online February 24, 2011, in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute.

row.title: Drugs Approved for Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
row.field_page_description: A list of cancer drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The list includes generic names, brand names, and common drug combinations.

row.title: Development of Physiologic Tissue Models to Assess Tumor Explant Response to Immune Checkpoint Blockade
row.field_short_title: Development of Physiologic Tissue Models to Assess Tumor Explant Response to Immune Checkpoint Block
row.field_page_description: This study seeks to better predict patient-derived tumor responsiveness to immune checkpoint blockade.
row.field_list_description: This study hypothesizes that physiologic modeling of the tumor microenvironment through microfluidic culture will enhance the ability to predict patient-derived tumor responsiveness to immune checkpoint blockade.

row.title: FDA Approves Alectinib For Initial Treatment of ALK-Positive Lung Cancer
row.field_short_title: FDA Approves Alectinib for Untreated ALK-Positive Lung Cancer
row.field_page_description: Alectinib (Alcensa) has been approved by the FDA for untreated ALK-positive non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), based on results from the ALEX trial.
row.field_feature_card_description: Approval offers new option for patients whose tumors are ALK positive.
row.field_list_description: FDA has approved alectinib (Alecensa) as a first-line treatment option for patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer that is ALK positive. Alectinib is the third ALK inhibitor to be approved in this setting.

row.title: With Advances in Cancer Immunotherapy, Scientists Discuss Need to Develop New Mouse Models
row.field_short_title: Researchers Discuss Developing Better Cancer Immunotherapy Models
row.field_page_description: Developing better cancer immunotherapy mouse models was the focus of a recent NCI-sponsored meeting, including current challenges and future opportunities.
row.field_feature_card_description: Research symposium addresses need for new models to advance immune-based treatments.
row.field_list_description: A recent NCI symposium focused on developing new and better mouse models for testing treatments that harness the immune system against cancer.

row.title: Genomic Profiling Tests Cleared by FDA Can Help Guide Cancer Treatment, Clinical Trial Enrollment
row.field_short_title: FDA Approves Two Genomic Profiling Tests for Cancer
row.field_page_description: FDA has approved two genomic profiling tests for tumors. One of the tests, FoundationOne CDx (F1CDx), can be used as a companion diagnostic for some cancer therapies.
row.field_feature_card_description: Tests can identify different cancer-associated genetic alterations.
row.field_list_description: The FDA has recently approved two tests to identify genetic alterations in tumors. One of the tests can be used to identify patients who may be candidates to receive specific targeted therapies.

row.title: Fusobacterium May Help Colorectal Cancer Grow and Spread
row.field_short_title: Bacteria May Aid Growth of Colorectal Cancer
row.field_page_description: The bacteria Fusobacterium may help fuel the growth of colorectal cancer, and antibiotics may help to treat it, a new study suggests.
row.field_feature_card_description: Study links specific bacterial species to growth, spread of this common cancer.
row.field_list_description: Fusobacterium, found in the stomach and intestines, may help fuel the growth of colorectal cancer and metastases. In a mouse model of colorectal cancer, using antibiotics to kill these bacteria slowed tumor growth.

row.title: NCI Scientists in the Community
Treatment of Head and Neck Cancer in Adults—Patient Version
row.field_short_title: Head and Neck Cancer Treatment in Adults
row.field_page_description: Find diagnosis, staging, and treatment information for these head and neck cancers: hypopharynx, larynx, lip and oral cavity, neck cancer with occult primary, nasopharynx, oropharynx, paranasal sinus and nasal cavity, and salivary gland cancer.

row.title: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC)
row.field_page_description: As the leading economic forum in the Asia-Pacific region, APEC facilitates economic growth and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region through trade and investment liberalization, business facilitation, and economic and technical cooperation.

row.title: Structural Biology and Molecular Applications Research
row.field_short_title: Structural Biology and Molecular Applications Research
row.field_page_description: Part of NCI's Division of Cancer Biology's research portfolio, research and development in this area focuses on enabling technologies, models, and methodologies to support basic and applied cancer research.
row.field_feature_card_description: Cancer research and development in this area focuses on enabling technologies, models, and methodologies to support basic and applied cancer research.
row.field_list_description: Cancer research and discovery in this area focuses on technology development and molecular applications, biophysical biology, and computational/mathematical methods and bioinformatics development.

row.title: Tumor Biology and Microenvironment Research
row.field_page_description: Part of NCI's Division of Cancer Biology's research portfolio, research in this area seeks to understand the role of tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment (TME) in driving cancer initiation, progression, maintenance and recurrence.
row.field_feature_card_description: Research in this area seeks to understand the role of tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment (TME) in driving cancer initiation, progression, maintenance and recurrence.
row.field_list_description: Research in this area seeks to understand the role of tumor cells and the tumor microenvironment in driving cancer processes. Understanding the cellular, molecular, and biochemical interactions of tumors within their microenvironment is essential to improving cancer diagnosis and treatment.

row.title: CGH Celebrates World Cancer Day 2017
row.field_page_description: The NCI Center for Global Health participated in a number of events to celebrate World Cancer Day.

row.title: Persistent Peripheral Neuropathy Increases Fall Risk among Cancer Survivors
row.field_short_title: Persistent Peripheral Neuropathy Increases Fall Risk among Cancer Survivors
row.field_page_description: Many female cancer survivors have problems with mobility and other physical functioning as a result of persistent peripheral neuropathy caused by chemotherapy treatment, according to a new study.
row.field_feature_card_description: Persistent neuropathy caused by chemotherapy impairs physical functioning and increases fall risk.

row.title: Extensive Lymph Node Surgery Does Not Increase Survival in Melanoma
row.field_short_title: Trial Provides Guidance on Lymph Node Surgery in Melanoma
row.field_page_description: An NCI Cancer Currents blog post on results from a clinical trial which show that a conservative approach to lymph node removal surgery may be best for some patients with melanoma.
row.field_feature_card_description: For some patients, a conservative approach may be best option.
row.field_list_description: A conservative approach to lymph node removal surgery may be best for people with melanoma that has spread from the skin to one or a small number of nearby lymph nodes, new results from a large international clinical trial suggest.

row.title: Cancer Researchers Report Progress in Studying Exceptional Responders
row.field_page_description: An NCI Cancer Currents blog post about a recent NCI-sponsored meeting to discuss research on exceptional responders—patients with cancer who have dramatic and long-lasting treatment responses.
row.field_feature_card_description: Researchers are trying to identify factors behind unique, dramatic treatment responses.
row.field_list_description: Researchers who study exceptional responders—patients who have dramatic and long-lasting responses to treatments for cancer that were not effective for most similar patients—met recently to discuss the state of the science in this emerging field.

row.title: Understanding Cervical Changes: Next Steps After an Abnormal Screening Test
row.field_page_description: Explains abnormal Pap test, HPV test, and Pap/HPV cotest results. Treatment and follow-up care for abnormal cervical cancer screening results including ASC-US, AGC, LSIL, ASC-H, HSIL, AIS. Learn about colposcopy, types of biopsies, CIN, and HPV vaccine.
row.field_feature_card_description: Explains HPV Infection; cervical cancer screening tests including Pap test, HPV test, and Pap/HPV cotesting; new cervical cancer screening guidelines; possible Pap test results and Pap/HPV cotest results; follow-up testing; treatment; and HPV vaccination.
row.field_list_description: Learn what test results mean if a recent Pap test showed cell changes in the cervix or an HPV test was positive, including that not all cervical changes mean cancer; find out the importance of follow-up care and treatment for abnormal results.

row.title: Targeted Therapy to Treat Cancer
row.field_page_description: Targeted therapy is a type of cancer treatment that targets the changes in cancer cells that help them grow, divide, and spread. Learn how targeted therapy works against cancer and about side effects that may occur.
row.field_feature_card_description: Targeted therapy is a type of cancer treatment that targets the changes in cancer cells that help them grow, divide, and spread. Learn how targeted therapy works against cancer and about side effects that may occur.
row.field_list_description: Targeted therapy is a type of cancer treatment that targets the changes in cancer cells that help them grow, divide, and spread. Learn how targeted therapy works against cancer and about common side effects that may occur.

row.title: Checking In on Cancer Checkpoint Inhibitors
row.field_short_title: Checking In on Cancer Checkpoint Inhibitors
row.field_page_description: NCI’s Dr. James Gulley discusses cancer checkpoint inhibitors, their impact on patient care, and future directions for these therapies.

row.title: Cancer Can Lead to Financial Hardship, Study Confirms
row.field_short_title: Study of Cancer and Financial Hardship
row.field_page_description: A substantial number of working-age cancer survivors report material or psychological financial hardship associated with their cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Many working-age cancer survivors report financial hardship associated with their cancer.

row.title: DNA Misfolding Revealed as Novel Oncogenic Mechanism
row.field_short_title: DNA Misfolding Revealed as Novel Oncogenic Mechanism
row.field_page_description: Researchers studying IDH-mutant brain tumors have identified a previously unknown genetic mechanism that may contribute to cancer. A change in how DNA is arranged, or packaged, in the cell nucleus may inappropriately activate a gene associated with brain cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: DNA Misfolding Revealed as Novel Oncogenic Mechanism

row.title: Penile Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: Find research articles on penile cancer, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.
row.field_feature_card_description: Find research articles on penile cancer, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.

row.title: Breast Cancer—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Breast cancer is the second most common cancer in women after skin cancer. Mammograms can detect breast cancer early, possibly before it has spread. Start here to find information on breast cancer treatment, causes and prevention, screening, research, and statistics.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information about breast cancer prevention, screening, treatment, statistics, research, clinical trials, and more.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about breast cancer.

row.title: Lasers in Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that describes use of high-intensity light in cancer treatment, its advantages and disadvantages, and types of procedures that use it.

row.title: Angiogenesis Inhibitors
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that describes cancer-fighting agents that block the growth of blood vessels that support tumor growth.

row.title: Contact Us for Help
row.field_page_description: Cancer information specialists can answer your questions about cancer and help you with quitting smoking. They also respond to questions and requests for information about NCI and its programs.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI offers free information on cancer topics in English and Spanish. Get live help at 1-800-4-CANCER.

row.title: Study Suggests Smaller Melanoma Excision Margins May Be Option for Some Patients
row.field_short_title: Study Suggests Smaller Melanoma Excision Margins May Be Option for Some Patients
row.field_page_description: A randomized controlled trial of patients with stage IIA–C cutaneous melanoma thicker than 2-mm found that a 2-cm surgical resection margin is sufficient and is as safe for patients as a 4-cm margin.
row.field_feature_card_description: A randomized controlled trial of patients with stage IIA–C cutaneous melanoma thicker than 2-mm found that a 2-cm surgical resection margin is sufficient and is as safe for patients as a 4-cm margin.
row.field_list_description: A randomized controlled trial of patients with stage IIA–C cutaneous melanoma thicker than 2-mm found that a 2-cm surgical resection margin is sufficient and is as safe for patients as a 4-cm margin in terms of overall survival, according to a report published online October 21 in The Lancet.

row.title: Targeted Therapy Shows Benefit in Rare Type of Thyroid Cancer
row.field_short_title: Targeted Therapy Shows Benefit in Rare Type of Thyroid Cancer
row.field_page_description: Treatment with the multitargeted agent vandetanib (Caprelsa) improved progression-free survival in patients with medullary thyroid cancer (MTC), according to findings from a randomized clinical trial.
row.field_feature_card_description: Treatment with the multitargeted agent vandetanib (Caprelsa) improved progression-free survival in patients with medullary thyroid cancer (MTC), according to findings from a randomized clinical trial.

row.title: Questions to Ask Your Doctor When You Have Finished Treatment
row.field_short_title: Questions to Ask Your Doctor When You Have Finished Treatment
row.field_page_description: Suggested questions for cancer patients to ask their doctors after treatment is finished and they are planning for follow-up care and next steps.
row.field_feature_card_description: Suggested questions for cancer patients to ask their doctors after treatment is finished and they are planning for follow-up care and next steps.

row.title: RAS Reagents
row.field_page_description: The RAS Reagents group prepares proteins, DNAs, and cell lines, all of which are required to attack cancers caused by mutant RAS.
row.field_feature_card_description: Attacking cancers caused by mutant RAS requires proteins, DNAs, and cell lines prepared by this group.
row.field_list_description: Attacking cancers caused by mutant RAS requires proteins, DNAs, and cell lines prepared by this group.

row.title: FDA Approves Cobimetinib as Part of Drug Combination for Advanced Melanoma
row.field_page_description: The FDA has approved the targeted drug cobimetinib, in combination with another targeted therapy, to treat patients with advanced melanoma whose tumors have specific genetic mutations.
row.field_feature_card_description: Drug combination targets the same signaling pathway in cancer cells.

row.title: Returning to Vietnam – Building on Collaborations in Cancer Control and Research
row.field_short_title: Returning to Vietnam – Building on Collaborations in Cancer Control and Research
row.field_page_description: Dr. Paul Pearlman presented at the 9th US-Vietnam Joint Committee Meeting on Science and Technology Cooperation, held in Ho Chi Minh City by the Ministry of Science and Technology, and at a national cancer stakeholder meeting in Hanoi, held by the Ministry of Health.

row.title: Overcoming Global Cultural and Financial Disparities to Treat Children with Cancer
row.field_short_title: Overcoming Global Cultural and Financial Disparities to Treat Children with Cancer

row.title: Driving New Approaches to Cancer Prevention and Early Detection
row.field_short_title: Driving New Approaches to Cancer Prevention and Early Detection
row.field_page_description: Researchers are pioneering new approaches to preventing and screening for cancer, and the management of very early-stage disease.
row.field_feature_card_description: Researchers are pioneering new approaches to cancer screening and prevention, and the management of early-stage disease.

row.title: RAS Biochemistry and Biophysics
row.field_page_description: This RAS Biochemistry and Biophysics lab investigates signaling by RAS proteins, which is regulated by the interactions with substrates, protein partners, and membranes.
row.field_feature_card_description: Signaling by RAS proteins is regulated by the interactions with substrates, protein partners, and membranes that are investigated by this lab.
