row.title: Regorafenib Becomes First FDA-Approved Drug for Liver Cancer in Nearly a Decade
row.field_short_title: FDA Approves Regorafenib for Liver Cancer
row.field_page_description: An NCI Cancer Currents blog on FDA’s approval of regorafenib (Stivarga®), the first drug approved for liver cancer in nearly a decade.
row.field_feature_card_description: Regorafenib is the first drug approved for liver cancer in nearly a decade.
row.field_list_description: FDA approved the kinase inhibitor regorafenib for some patients with hepatocellular carcinoma, the most common form of liver cancer.

row.title: HPV Vaccination Linked to Decreased Oral HPV Infections
row.field_short_title: HPV Vaccine May Prevent Oral HPV Infection
row.field_page_description: An NCI Cancer Currents blog on a study showing that the HPV vaccine Gardasil may sharply reduce oral HPV infections linked to oropharyngeal cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: More than half of oropharyngeal cancers in the US are linked to HPV 16, which is covered by vaccines.
row.field_list_description: A study of more than 2,600 young adults found that the prevalence of oral infection with four HPV types, including two cancer-causing types, was 88% lower in those who reported receiving at least one dose of an HPV vaccine than in those not vaccinated.

row.title: Geraldina Dominguez, Ph.D.
Genomic Study Seeks Clues to Help Explain Breast Cancer Disparities
row.field_short_title: Genome Study of Breast Cancer in African Americans
row.field_page_description: A Cancer Currents blog on a genomic study that assessed the extent to which molecular characteristics of breast tumors may help to explain some breast cancer disparities.
row.field_feature_card_description: At a molecular level, tumors in blacks and whites are more similar than different.
row.field_list_description: Using one of the largest collections of tumor samples from African Americans with breast cancer, researchers tried to assess the extent to which the molecular characteristics on these tumors might help to explain breast cancer disparities.

row.title: CRCHD Announces New CURE Distinguished Scholars Seminar Series
row.field_page_description: In celebration of 21 years of the CURE program, CRCHD is pleased to announce a new scientific seminar series the CURE Distinguished Scholars Seminar Series.
row.field_feature_card_description: CRCHD is pleased to announce the CURE Distinguished Scholars Seminar Series.
row.field_list_description: In celebration of 21 years of the Continuing Umbrella of Research Experiences (CURE) program, CRCHD is pleased to announce a new scientific seminar series, the CURE Distinguished Scholars Seminar Series.

row.title: Survivors of Breast Cancer Differ on Who Should Manage Follow-Up Care
row.field_short_title: Breast Cancer Survivors’ Preferences on Follow-Up Care
row.field_page_description: Some survivors of early-stage breast cancer prefer that their oncologist handle aspects of their routine follow-up care, according to a new study discussed in this Cancer Currents blog post.
row.field_feature_card_description: Breast cancer survivors have varied opinions about who should handle follow-up care.
row.field_list_description: Many survivors of early-stage breast cancer prefer that their oncologist handle aspects of routine medical care usually overseen by primary care practitioners, leading to concerns about gaps in care.

row.title: Study Uncovers Previously Unrecognized Effect of Chemotherapy
row.field_page_description: A study conducted primarily in mice suggests that pre-surgical chemotherapy in breast cancer can cause changes in cells in and around the tumor that aid metastasis.
row.field_feature_card_description: Study in mice suggests chemotherapy could aid metastasis.
row.field_list_description: A new study conducted primarily in mice suggests that chemotherapy given before surgery for breast cancer can cause changes in cells in and around the tumor that are tied to an increased risk of the cancer spreading to other areas of the body.

row.title: We've Updated Clinical Trials
Manage Your Award
Heart Attack, Stroke Risk May Be Elevated Following Cancer Diagnosis
row.field_short_title: Heart Attack, Stroke Risk Elevated Following Cancer Diagnosis
row.field_page_description: A cancer diagnosis can come with an increased risk of a heart attack or stroke in the months after beginning treatment, a new study suggests.
row.field_feature_card_description: Highest risk seen in lung cancer, advanced cancers.
row.field_list_description: A diagnosis of cancer can come with an increased risk of a heart attack or stroke in the months after beginning treatment, a new study suggests. Within 6 months of a diagnosis, the risk of either event was more than twice that seen in people without cancer.

row.title: Secondhand Smoke and Cancer
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that summarizes the studies on the health effects of exposure to environmental (secondhand) tobacco smoke.
row.field_feature_card_description: Harmful chemicals in the smoke inhaled by smokers are also found in environmental (secondhand) tobacco smoke.

row.title: Vaginal Cancer—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Two-thirds of vaginal cancer cases are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Vaccines that protect against infection with HPV may reduce the risk of vaginal cancer. When found early, vaginal cancer can often be cured. Start here to find information on vaginal cancer treatment and research.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about vaginal cancer.

row.title: Plasma Cell Neoplasms (Including Multiple Myeloma)—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Plasma cell neoplasms occur when abnormal plasma cells form cancerous tumors. When there is only one tumor, the disease is called a plasmacytoma. When there are multiple tumors, it is called multiple myeloma. Start here to find information on plasma cell neoplasms treatment, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: Information about multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms. Learn about treatment, clinical trials, research, and statistics from the National Cancer Institute.

row.title: Eliminating Hairy Cell Leukemia Minimal Residual Disease
row.field_short_title: Eliminating Hairy Cell Leukemia Minimal Residual Disease
row.field_page_description: In this trial, patients with hairy cell leukemia who have disease-related symptoms that require treatment will be randomly assigned to receive cladribine with either concurrent rituximab or rituximab at least 6 months after completing cladribine therapy.
row.field_list_description: In this trial, patients with hairy cell leukemia who have disease-related symptoms that require treatment, and who have not been treated or have had only one prior treatment with cladribine, will be randomly assigned to receive cladribine with either concurrent rituximab or rituximab at least 6 months after completing cladribine therapy.

row.title: Exemestane Following Tamoxifen Reduces Breast Cancer Recurrences and Prolongs Survival
row.field_short_title: Exemestane Following Tamoxifen Reduces Breast Cancer Recurrences and Prolongs Survival
row.field_page_description: Postmenopausal women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer had delayed disease recurrence and longer survival after taking 2-3 years of tamoxifen followed by exemestane for a total of 5 years compared to taking tamoxifen for 5 years.
row.field_feature_card_description: Postmenopausal women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer had delayed disease recurrence and longer survival after taking 2-3 years of tamoxifen followed by exemestane for a total of 5 years compared to taking tamoxifen for 5 years.
row.field_list_description: Long-term follow-up data from a large international phase III trial shows that postmenopausal women with early-stage hormone receptor-positive breast cancer who received 2 to 3 years of tamoxifen and then switched to the drug exemestane (Aromasin®) for a total of 5 years of adjuvant hormone therapy experienced a delay in disease recurrence and a survival advantage, compared with women who took tamoxifen for 5 years.

row.title: Bladder Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: Find research articles on bladder cancer, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.

row.title: Stomach (Gastric) Cancer—Health Professional Version
row.field_page_description: Almost all gastric cancers are adenocarcinomas. Other types of gastric cancer are gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors, gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and lymphomas. Find evidence-based information on gastric cancer treatment, causes and prevention, screening, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about stomach (gastric) cancer.

row.title: Head and Neck Cancer—Health Professional Version
row.field_page_description: Head and neck cancers include hypopharyngeal, laryngeal, lip and oral cavity, metastatic squamous neck, nasopharyngeal, oropharyngeal, paranasal sinus, and salivary gland cancers. Find evidence-based information on head and neck cancer treatment, causes and prevention, research, screening, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about head and neck cancer.

row.title: Leukemia Research
row.field_page_description: Find research articles on leukemia, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.

row.title: Myeloproliferative Neoplasms—Health Professional Version
row.field_page_description: Myeloproliferative neoplasms and myelodysplastic syndromes are diseases of the blood cells. They include chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms, myelodysplastic syndromes, and myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms. Find evidence-based information on myeloproliferative neoplasms treatment.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about Myeloproliferative Neoplasms.

row.title: Prostate Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: Find research articles on prostate cancer, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.

row.title: Video Eases End-of-Life Care Discussions
row.field_page_description: Patients with advanced cancer who watched a video that depicts options for end-of-life care were more certain of their end-of-life decision making than patients who only listened to a verbal narrative.
row.field_feature_card_description: Patients with advanced cancer who watched a video that depicts options for end-of-life care were more certain of their end-of-life decision making than patients who only listened to a verbal narrative.
row.field_list_description: Patients with advanced cancer who watched a video that depicts options for end-of-life care were more certain of their end-of-life decision making than patients who only listened to a verbal narrative and were likely to choose comfort care over aggressive medical care for their end-of-life care preferences, according to an article published online November 30, 2009, in the Journal of Clinical Oncology.

row.title: NCI Dictionary of Genetics Terms
row.field_page_description: A dictionary of more than 150 genetics-related terms written for healthcare professionals. This resource was developed to support the comprehensive, evidence-based, peer-reviewed PDQ cancer genetics information summaries.
row.field_feature_card_description: A dictionary of more than 150 genetics-related terms written for healthcare professionals, developed to support the comprehensive, evidence-based, peer-reviewed PDQ cancer genetics information summaries.

row.title: Phases of Clinical Trials
row.field_page_description: Information about the phases of cancer clinical trials. If a new treatment is successful in one phase, it will proceed to further testing in the next phase.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information about the phases of cancer clinical trials.

row.title: National Lung Screening Trial: Questions and Answers
row.field_short_title: National Lung Screening Trial: Questions and Answers
row.field_page_description: Learn the results of the National Lung Screening Trial (NLST), which compared two ways of detecting lung cancer: low-dose helical (spiral) computed tomography and standard chest X-ray, for their effects on lung cancer death rates in a high-risk population.

row.title: India Models New Institute on NCI
row.field_short_title: India Models New Institute on NCI
row.field_page_description: Health officials in India recently announced that the country of 1.25 billion is establishing a national cancer institute, which will be modeled after the U.S. National Cancer Institute (NCI).

row.title: Risk Factors for Cancer
row.field_page_description: Information about behaviors, exposures, and other factors that may influence the risk of cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information about behaviors, exposures, and other factors that may influence your risk of cancer.

row.title: NCI Mobile Apps
row.field_page_description: Download free mobile apps from the National Cancer Institute, including apps for smoking cessation support and the training of the next generation of cancer researchers.

row.title: The RAS Problem: Turning Off a Broken Switch
row.field_short_title: The RAS Problem: Turning Off a Broken Switch
row.field_page_description: The RAS gene is commonly mutated in cancer and researchers are working to better understand how to develop drugs that can target the RAS protein, which for many years has been considered to be “undruggable.”
row.field_feature_card_description: The RAS gene is commonly mutated in cancer and researchers are working to better understand how to develop drugs that can target the RAS protein, which for many years has been considered to be “undruggable.”

row.title: A Week of Excitement and Hope: Communicating the Story of Cancer
row.field_short_title: A Week of Excitement and Hope: Communicating the Story of Cancer
row.field_page_description: Peter Garrett, acting director of NCI's communications office, discusses the Annual Report to the Nation on the Status of Cancer and activities surrounding the broadcast of the documentary film, Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies.

row.title: Looking to the Future of Childhood Cancer Research
row.field_short_title: Looking to the Future of Childhood Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: NCI’s Dr. Malcolm Smith discusses future directions of childhood cancer research, including treatment directions and clinical trials.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI’s Dr. Malcolm Smith discusses future directions of childhood cancer research, including treatment directions and clinical trials.

row.title: Reports, Research, and Literature
row.field_page_description: Reports and research projects that address the special challenges facing adolescents and young adults with cancer and provide details about incidence, outcomes, and survival for this population.
row.field_feature_card_description: Reports and research projects that address the special challenges facing adolescents and young adults with cancer.

row.title: The Cancer Genome Atlas: Generating a "Parts List" for Cancer
row.field_short_title: The Cancer Genome Atlas: Generating a "Parts List" for Cancer
row.field_page_description: Jean-Claude Zenklusen, Ph.D., discusses the accomplishments and future of The Cancer Genome Atlas, inspired by topics covered in the documentary film, Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies.

row.title: PDQ® Cancer Information Summaries
row.field_page_description: Peer-reviewed, evidence-based summaries on topics including adult and pediatric cancer treatment, supportive and palliative care, screening, prevention, genetics, and complementary and alternative medicine. References to published literature are included.
row.field_feature_card_description: PDQ cancer information summaries are peer-reviewed and evidence-based, for patients and professionals.
row.field_list_description: PDQ cancer information summaries are peer-reviewed, evidence-based summaries on topics including adult and pediatric cancer treatment, supportive and palliative care, screening, prevention, genetics, and complementary and alternative medicine, typically available in both a Patient and Health Professional format.

row.title: PDQ® Levels of Evidence
row.field_page_description: PDQ cancer information summaries include level-of-evidence designations to help readers understand the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches.
row.field_feature_card_description: Levels of evidence are determined by each PDQ Editorial Board, and refer to the strength of evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches.

row.title: Turning Evidence into Practice
row.field_page_description: CGH CRTA, Hillary Topazian, attended the National Cancer Institute’s 3rd Symposium on Global Cancer Research; a satellite meeting to the 6th Annual Consortium of Universities for Global Health (CUGH) Conference in Boston. The Symposium centered on the theme of implementation science, a field which studies the integrati

row.title: Advancing Cancer Care Delivery Research in the Next Decade
row.field_short_title: Advancing Cancer Care Delivery Research in the Next Decade
row.field_page_description: NCI’s new Healthcare Delivery Research Program (HDRP) will focus on advancing the science of cancer care delivery in ways that improve survival and enhance patient care experiences.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI’s new Healthcare Delivery Research Program (HDRP) will focus on advancing the science of cancer care delivery in ways that improve survival and enhance patient care experiences.
row.field_list_description: A more substantial and coordinated effort is needed to advance the science of cancer care delivery to help address the complex problems facing our health care systems. In response, NCI has created a new Healthcare Delivery Research Program (HDRP) to strengthen its support and coordination of research in ways that both improve survival and enhance patient care experiences.

row.title: 2014 Press Releases
row.field_page_description: Press releases from the National Cancer Institute for the year 2014.

row.title: Treatment Research
row.field_page_description: Find research articles on cancer treatment, including news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.
row.field_list_description: Find research articles on cancer treatment, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.

row.title: Grants & Training
row.field_page_description: Information about grants and other funding opportunities, the NCI grants process, and funding for training.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information about grants and other funding opportunities, the NCI grants process, and funding for training.

row.title: Collateral Damage: Missing Tumor Suppressor Gene Creates Opening for Cancer Treatment
row.field_short_title: Missing Tumor Suppressor Gene Creates Treatment Opportunity
row.field_page_description: Tumor cells that are missing one copy of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 often harbor another genetic alteration that may make them susceptible to a targeted attack, according to a new study.
row.field_feature_card_description: Tumor cells missing one copy of the TP53 gene may be susceptible to a targeted attack.

row.title: Ras: Do We Know Its Structure Well Enough?
row.field_short_title: Ras: Do We Know Its Structure Well Enough?
row.field_page_description: Carla Mattos discusses how subtle changes in distant parts of RAS molecules may influence the conversion of GTP to GDP that is fundamental to RAS signaling.

row.title: Dr. Stefan Ambs: Increasing Diversity in Cancer Research: One Lab at a Time
row.field_short_title: Dr. Stefan Ambs: Increasing Diversity in Cancer Research: One Lab at a Time
row.field_page_description: As part of the series “Increasing Diversity in Cancer Research,” CRCHD interviewed Dr. Stefan Ambs, an investigator at NCI’s Center for Cancer Research, who is using novel approaches to discover gene differences in the tumors of African American patients.
row.field_feature_card_description: Dr. Ambs investigates gene differences in the tumors of African American patients.

row.title: Research Programs and Initiatives
row.field_page_description: CGH develops international initiatives and collaborates with other NCI divisions, NCI-designated Cancer Centers, and other countries to support cancer control planning, encourage capacity building, and support cancer research and research networks.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn about our international research programs and initiatives which promote knowledge sharing in cancer research and cancer control.
row.field_list_description: Learn about our international research programs and initiatives which promote knowledge sharing in cancer research and cancer control.

row.title: The "Accidental" Cure—Platinum-based Treatment for Cancer: The Discovery of Cisplatin
row.field_short_title: Use of Cisplatin for Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Prior to the discovery of cisplatin in 1965, men with testicular cancer had few medical options. Now, thanks to NCI research, cisplatin and similar chemotherapy drugs are known for curing testicular and other forms of cancer.

row.title: Cancer Detection, Diagnosis, and Treatment Technologies for Global Health
row.field_short_title: Cancer Detection, Diagnosis, and Treatment Technologies for Global Health

row.title: United States-Latin America Cancer Research Network (US-LA CRN)
row.field_short_title: United States-Latin America Cancer Research Network (US-LA CRN)
row.field_page_description: The US–LA CRN was established in 2009 to increase cancer research capacity in Latin America. NCI formalized bilateral agreements with the governments of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, Puerto Rico, and Uruguay, to facilitate interactions at the government, institution, and investigator levels.
row.field_feature_card_description: The US–LA CRN was established in 2009 to increase cancer research capacity in Latin America.

row.title: The Global Cancer Research Story
row.field_page_description: In 2012 alone, nearly 8.2 million people worldwide died from cancer and its predicted that 13.2 people will die in 2030.

row.title: Gynecologic Cancers Steering Committee
row.field_page_description: The Gynecologic Cancers Steering Committee evaluates and prioritizes concepts for phase 2 and 3 clinical trials in adult gynecologic cancers. The GCSC is also intent on fostering collaboration with international groups and institutions conducting trials.
row.field_feature_card_description: The Gynecologic Cancers Steering Committee evaluates and prioritizes concepts for phase 3 and large phase 2 therapeutic clinical trials.
row.field_list_description: The Gynecologic Cancers Steering Committee evaluates and prioritizes concepts for phase 3 and large phase 2 therapeutic clinical trials to be conducted in the NCI National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN).

row.title: Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial (PCPT): Questions and Answers
row.field_short_title: Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial (PCPT): Questions and Answers
row.field_page_description: Learn the results of the Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial, which was a study designed to see whether the drug finasteride (trade name Proscar) could prevent prostate cancer in men ages 55 and older.

row.title: Chronic Inflammation
row.field_page_description: Information about how chronic inflammation can lead to cancer.

row.title: Global Cancer Humanitarian Award Honors Pat Garcia-Gonzalez of the Max Foundation
row.field_page_description: Pat Garcia-Gonzalez of the Max Foundation accepted the first annual NCI Global Cancer Medicine Humanitarian Award for her work in chronic myeloid leukemia at the NCI, Center for Global Health Symposium for Global Cancer Research, held in Boston on March 25, 2015.

row.title: NCI Dictionaries
row.field_page_description: Links to NCI's three main dictionaries; the NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms, the NCI Dictionary of Genetics Terms, and the NCI Drug Dictionary.
row.field_feature_card_description: Links to NCI's dictionaries of cancer terms, genetics terms and cancer drug terms.

row.title: Grantee Spotlight: Kurt Richard Weiss, M.D. - From Osteosarcoma Survivor to Osteosarcoma Researcher
row.field_short_title: Grantee Spotlight: Kurt Richard Weiss, M.D. - From Osteosarcoma Survivor to Osteosarcoma Researcher
row.field_page_description: Dr. Kurt Richard Weiss, NCI/CRCHD K08 recipient and osteosarcoma survivor, research focuses on identifying the factors and mechanisms related to osteosarcoma cell metastasis.
row.field_feature_card_description: Dr. Weiss researches factors and mechanisms related to osteosarcoma cell metastasis.

row.title: Common Cancer Types
row.field_page_description: List of common cancer types, or cancers that are diagnosed with the greatest frequency in the United States; provides most recent incidence and mortality statistics for these cancers.
row.field_list_description: This list of common cancer types includes cancers that are diagnosed with the greatest frequency in the United States; provides most recent incidence and mortality statistics for these cancers.

row.title: HPV Vaccine Effective Against Infection at Multiple Sites, Provides Partial Protection in Women with Previous Infections
row.field_short_title: HPV Vaccine Effective at Multiple Anatomic Sites
row.field_page_description: A new study from NCI researchers finds that the HPV vaccine protects young women from infection with high-risk HPV types at the three primary anatomic sites where persistent HPV infections can cause cancer. The multi-site protection also was observed at l
row.field_list_description: A new study from NCI researchers finds that the HPV vaccine protects young women from infection with high-risk HPV types at the three primary anatomic sites where persistent HPV infections can cause cancer. The multi-site protection also was observed at lower levels in previously HPV-exposed women.

row.title: NCI Dictionary of Cancer Terms Widget
row.field_page_description: Tool for websites to let users look up cancer-related terms
row.field_feature_card_description: Tool for websites to let users look up cancer-related terms

row.title: For Some Skin Cancers, Targeted Drug Hits the Mark
row.field_short_title: For Some Skin Cancers, Targeted Drug Hits the Mark
row.field_page_description: Two studies reported June 7, 2012, in NEJM indicate that the drug vismodegib can elicit responses in people with advanced or metastatic basal cell carcinoma and help shrink or prevent tumors in those with basal cell nevus syndrome.
row.field_feature_card_description: Two studies reported June 7, 2012, in NEJM indicate that the drug vismodegib can elicit responses in people with advanced or metastatic basal cell carcinoma and help shrink or prevent tumors in those with basal cell nevus syndrome.
row.field_list_description: Two studies reported June 7, 2012, in the New England Journal of Medicine indicate that the drug vismodegib (Erivedge™) can elicit responses in people with advanced or metastatic basal cell carcinoma and help shrink or prevent tumors in those with basal cell nevus syndrome.

row.title: Coordinating Center for Clinical Trials (CCCT)
row.field_page_description: The Coordinating Center for Clinical Trials (CCCT) plays a key role in supporting NCI’s clinical and translational research programs to advance science and patient care.
row.field_feature_card_description: Coordinates the integration of NCI's clinical and associated translational research programs.

row.title: FDA Approves First Therapy for High-Risk Neuroblastoma
row.field_short_title: FDA Approves First Therapy for High-Risk Neuroblastoma
row.field_page_description: The FDA has approved dinutuximab as part of first-line therapy for children with high-risk neuroblastoma.
row.field_feature_card_description: The FDA has approved dinutuximab (Unituxin™) as part of first-line therapy for children with high-risk neuroblastoma.

row.title: Childhood Cancers
row.field_page_description: Information about the common types of pediatric cancers, the latest treatments, where to go for treatment, and where to find information about coping and survivorship.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information and resources for understanding the basics of pediatric cancers.

row.title: NCI Director Dr. Norman E. Sharpless
row.field_page_description: Information about NCI Director Dr. Norman E. Sharpless
row.field_feature_card_description: Information about NCI Director Dr. Norman E. Sharpless

row.title: 2015 Press Releases
row.field_page_description: Press releases from the National Cancer Institute for the year 2015.

row.title: Microscopy Advances Open Up New Avenues of Cancer Discovery
row.field_short_title: Microscopy Opening Up New Cancer Discovery Avenues
row.field_page_description: Today’s high-powered microscopes are allowing researchers to study the fine details of individual cells and to peer into cells, opening up new avenues of discovery about the inner workings of cells, including the events that can cause healthy cells to tra
row.field_list_description: Today’s high-powered microscopes are allowing researchers to study the fine details of individual cells and to peer into cells, opening up new avenues of discovery about the inner workings of cells, including the events that can cause healthy cells to transform into cancer cells.

row.title: Grantee Spotlight: Shawna Hudson, Ph.D. - Helping Cancer Survivors EXCEL
row.field_short_title: Grantee Spotlight: Shawna Hudson, Ph.D. - Helping Cancer Survivors EXCEL
row.field_page_description: Dr. Shawna Hudson, an NCI/CRCHD K01 awardee, works to ensure cancer survivors continue to stay in touch with their physicians and seek the follow-up care they need.
row.field_feature_card_description: Dr. Hudson works to ensure cancer survivors receive necessary follow-up care.

row.title: Special Spotlight: In Memoriam Alessandra Margherita Bini, Ph.D. CRCHD Program Director
row.field_short_title: Special Spotlight: In Memoriam Alessandra Margherita Bini, Ph.D. CRCHD Program Director
row.field_page_description: CRCHD remembers our friend and colleague, Dr. Alessandra Margherita Bini. Dr. Bini, a Program Director in CRCHD’s Diversity Training Branch, passed away February 26, 2014.
row.field_feature_card_description: CRCHD remembers our friend and colleague, Dr. Alessandra Margherita Bini.

row.title: Special Spotlight: In Memoriam Patricia Susana Lorenzo, Ph.D. Cancer Researcher and Former CRCHD Grantee
row.field_short_title: Special Spotlight: In Memoriam Patricia Susana Lorenzo, Ph.D.
row.field_page_description: CRCHD celebrates the life and work of Dr. Patricia Susana Lorenzo, a compassionate woman, friend, colleague, wife, and dedicated researcher.
row.field_feature_card_description: CRCHD celebrates the life and work of Dr. Patricia Susana Lorenzo.

row.title: Enzymology of GTP-competitive RAS inhibitors
row.field_page_description: RAS molecules have affinities for GTP and GDP that are in the picomolar range. Ken Westover argues that covalent inhibitors of RAS are logical drug candidates.

row.title: Adrenocortical Carcinoma—Health Professional Version
row.field_page_description: Adrenocortical carcinoma is also called cancer of the adrenal cortex. A tumor of the adrenal cortex may be functioning or nonfunctioning. Most adrenocortical tumors are functioning. Find evidence-based information on adrenocortical carcinoma including treatment and research.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about adrenocortical carcinoma.

row.title: Anal Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: Find research articles on anal cancer, which may include news stories, clinical trials, blog posts, and descriptions of active studies.

row.title: Extracranial Germ Cell Tumors—Health Professional Version
row.field_page_description: Extracranial germ cell tumors (GCTs) arise from primordial germ cells, which migrate during embryogenesis from the yolk sac to the gonads. Childhood extracranial GCTs can be divided into the following two types: gonadal, and extragonadal. Find evidence-based information on extracranial germ cell tumors treatment.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about extracranial germ cell tumors.

row.title: Cancer Clusters
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that describes what constitutes a cancer cluster and the process for reporting and investigating suspected clusters.
row.field_list_description: A fact sheet that describes what constitutes a cancer cluster, the process for reporting and investigating suspected clusters, and the challenges in investigating suspected clusters.

row.title: Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) Test
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that describes the PSA screening test for prostate cancer and explains the benefits and limitations of the test.

row.title: Contact the Center for Cancer Training
row.field_page_description: Contact staff at the Center for Cancer Training and read staff bios.
row.field_list_description: Program contacts for NCI training programs.

row.title: Training
row.field_page_description: NCI offers training at laboratories and clinics in Maryland and at universities and institutions nationwide. These cancer training and career development opportunities cover a broad spectrum of disciplines for individuals at career stages ranging from high school and graduate students to scientists, clinicians, and hea
row.field_feature_card_description: CCT supports NCI's goal of training cancer researchers for the 21st century.

row.title: When Your Parent Has Cancer: A Guide for Teens
row.field_short_title: When Your Parent Has Cancer: A Guide for Teens
row.field_page_description: Help for teens whose mom or dad has cancer. Learn how families cope and find support when a parent has cancer. Tips to help you talk with your friends, deal with stress, and take care of your mind and body are also shared.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information for teens and children who have a parent with cancer.
row.field_list_description: Information to help teens cope and find support when a parent has cancer. Help for teens whose mom or dad has cancer. Knowing how the cancer will be treated can help you to manage. Get tips to take care of yourself, talk with your friends, and help your parent and siblings.

row.title: Policies
row.field_page_description: Learn about the policies governing the National Cancer Institute’s website, including accessibility, comments, privacy and security, reuse of graphics and text, and more.

row.title: Reuse of NCI Information
row.field_page_description: Find information about use of NCI information, registered trademarks, and copyrighted material.
row.field_list_description: Information about use of NCI information, registered trademarks, and copyrighted material.

row.title: Freedom of Information Act
row.field_page_description: Learn about the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and how it provides individuals with a right to access information in the possession of the U.S. federal government.
row.field_feature_card_description: The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) provides individuals with a right to access information in the possession of the U.S. federal government.
row.field_list_description: The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) provides individuals with a right to access information in the possession of the U.S. federal government.

row.title: Grantee Spotlight: Julie Dang, M.P.H. - Personalizing Outreach to Address Asian Cancer Health Disparities
Grantee Spotlight: Nathan Ellis, Ph.D. Seeks Molecular Basis of Colorectal Cancer Disparities in African Americans
row.field_page_description: Dr. Nathan Ames Ellis, a CRCHD U01 grantee, uses comparative population-genetic analysis to shed new light on cancer susceptibility and the biological basis of colorectal cancer disparities in African Americans.
row.field_feature_card_description: Dr. Ellis researches a biological basis of CRC disparities in African Americans.

row.title: Anal Cancer—Health Professional Version
row.field_page_description: Anal cancer is a rare malignancy and accounts for a small percentage of cancers of the lower alimentary tract. The most common type of anal cancer is squamous cell carcinoma in the anal canal. Find evidence-based information on anal cancer treatment, causes and prevention, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about anal cancer.

row.title: CGH Future Directions
row.field_page_description: Looking ahead, the Center for Global Health has three major future directions that will help to acheive NCI’s goal of advancing global cancer research, building expertise, and leveraging resources across nations to address the challenges of cancer and reduce cancer deaths worldwide.
row.field_feature_card_description: As cancer diseases and research continue to evolve, we too will move forward with stronger, more collaborative work.

row.title: Head and Neck Cancer—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Head and neck cancers include cancers in the larynx (voice box), throat, lips, mouth, nose, and salivary glands. Start here to find information on head and neck cancer treatment in adults and children, causes and prevention, screening, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: Information about head and neck cancer treatment, prevention, causes, screening, clinical trials, research and statistics from the National Cancer Institute.

row.title: Chemicals in Meat Cooked at High Temperatures and Cancer Risk
row.field_short_title: Chemicals in Meat Cooked at High Temperatures and Cancer Risk
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that explains how certain chemicals form in meat cooked using high-temperature methods. Includes results of research on consumption of these chemicals and cancer risk.
row.field_list_description: A fact sheet that explains how certain chemicals are formed in meat that is cooked using high-temperature methods, such as pan frying or grilling, and describes the results of research on the relationship between consumption of these chemicals and cancer risk.

row.title: News & Events
row.field_page_description: The latest cancer news from the U.S. government's principal agency for cancer research, plus resources designed for science writers and reporters.

row.title: Chemotherapy Less Toxic to the Heart May Be Option for Some Women with HER2-Positive Breast Cancer
row.field_short_title: Chemotherapy Less Toxic to the Heart May Be Option for Some Women with HER2-Positive Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: A nonanthracycline-containing chemotherapy regimen combined with the targeted therapy trastuzumab may be an option for some women with HER2-positive breast cancer, according to results from the BCIRG-006 trial.
row.field_feature_card_description: A nonanthracycline-containing chemotherapy regimen combined with the targeted therapy trastuzumab may be an option for some women with HER2-positive breast cancer, according to results from the BCIRG-006 trial.
row.field_list_description: A nonanthracycline-containing chemotherapy regimen combined with the targeted therapy trastuzumab may be an option for some women with HER2-positive breast cancer, according to results from the Breast Cancer International Research Group 006 (BCIRG-006) trial reported October 6, 2011, in the New England Journal of Medicine.

row.title: Velcade®: A New Tool in the Fight against Multiple Myeloma
row.field_short_title: Velcade® and the Fight against Multiple Myeloma
row.field_page_description: Velcade® represents a new type of anticancer drug called proteasome inhibitors. It has shown promise in the treatment of multiple myeloma, a cancer of the white blood cells. Velcade® is being studied for use in a variety of blood cancers and solid tumors.

row.title: Cancer Control Leadership Forums
row.field_page_description: The Cancer Control Leadership Forums help increase the capacity of participating countries to initiate or enhance cancer control planning and implementation in their respective countries.
row.field_feature_card_description: The Cancer Control Leadership Forums help increase the capacity of participating countries to initiate or enhance cancer control planning and implementation in their respective countries.

row.title: Trastuzumab Benefits Women with Locally Advanced or Inflammatory Breast Cancer
row.field_short_title: Trastuzumab Benefits Women with Locally Advanced or Inflammatory
row.field_page_description: Women treated with trastuzumab (Herceptin) and chemotherapy before surgery and trastuzumab again after surgery had a reduced risk of the disease recurring or progressing compared with women who received pre-surgical chemotherapy but no trastuzumab, accord
row.field_list_description: Women treated with trastuzumab (Herceptin) and chemotherapy before surgery and trastuzumab again after surgery had a reduced risk of the disease recurring or progressing compared with women who received pre-surgical chemotherapy but no trastuzumab, according to a study published in the January 30, 2010, Lancet.

row.title: Syndication Services
row.field_page_description: Information about Cancer.gov's content dissemination program, which makes cancer information available in XML format for use in Web sites and in other information products.

row.title: PDQ® Cancer Integrative, Alternative, and Complementary Therapies Editorial Board
row.field_page_description: Experts in the fields of oncology, pharmacology, natural products, drug discovery and development, traditional Chinese medicine, acupuncture, and homeopathy.

row.title: Breast Cancer Risk in American Women
row.field_short_title: Breast Cancer Risk in American Women
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that provides statistics about a woman’s risk of developing breast cancer and information about breast cancer risk factors.
row.field_feature_card_description: A fact sheet that provides statistics about a woman’s risk of developing breast cancer and information about breast cancer risk factors.

row.title: Vulvar Cancer—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Vulvar cancer usually forms slowly, most often on the vaginal lips or the sides of the vaginal opening. Having vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia or human papillomavirus (HPV) infection can increase the risk of developing vulvar cancer. Start here to find information on vulvar cancer treatment, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about vulvar cancer.

row.title: Long-Term Data from 20 Trials Confirm Tamoxifen’s Long-Lasting Benefit
row.field_short_title: Long-Term Data from 20 Trials Confirm Tamoxifen's Long-Lasting Benefit
row.field_page_description: Women with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer who received about 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen had a lower risk of recurrence in the 15 years after treatment than women who did not receive tamoxifen.
row.field_feature_card_description: Women with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer who received about 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen had a lower risk of recurrence in the 15 years after treatment than women who did not receive tamoxifen.
row.field_list_description: In an analysis of data from participants in 20 clinical trials, women with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer who received about 5 years of adjuvant treatment with tamoxifen had a lower risk of recurrence in the 15 years after starting treatment than women who did not receive tamoxifen.

row.title: Resources
row.field_page_description: Find helpful education materials, documents and essays, and online tools.
row.field_feature_card_description: Find helpful education materials, documents and essays, and online tools.

row.title: Cancer Clinical Trial Leadership and Management Program
row.field_short_title: Cancer Clinical Trial Leadership and Management Program

row.title: Angiosarcoma
row.field_page_description: Angiosarcoma is a rare cancer that develops in the inner lining of blood vessels and lymph vessels. Angiosarcomais a fast-growing cancer, so your doctors will treat it aggressively. Learn more about the diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis for this rare tumor.
row.field_feature_card_description: Angiosarcoma is a rare cancer that develops in the inner lining of blood vessels and lymph vessels.
row.field_list_description: Angiosarcoma is a rare cancer that develops in the inner lining of blood vessels and lymph vessels. This cancer can occur anywhere in the body, but most often is in the skin, breast, liver and spleen.

row.title: Clear cell renal carcinoma
Papillary renal cell carcinoma
The Role of Families and Caregivers of People with Rare Cancers
row.field_page_description: When your loved one has a rare cancer, it can affect your entire family.Caregivers often need to handle details of medical care and provide physical and emotional support. But there are many sources of support to help families cope and handle the stress of having a rare cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: When a loved one has a rare cancer, it can affect the entire family. Caregivers have a lot of responsibilities, but support is available.
row.field_list_description: When your loved one has a rare cancer, it can affect your entire family. Parents, spouses, adult children, or other loved ones often need to handle details of medical care and provide physical and emotional support. But there are many sources of support to help families cope and handle the stress of having a rare cancer.

row.title: Participating in a Clinical Trial for Rare Cancer
row.field_short_title: Participating in a Clinical Trial for Rare Cancer
row.field_page_description: When you are diagnosed with a rare cancer, you and your family may think about joining a clinical trial or study.You may get access to a new drug, or a chance to see world-renowned doctors. You are also helping future rare cancer patients by helping researchers today.
row.field_feature_card_description: By joining a clinical trial or study, you may get access to a new drug, or a chance to see world-renowned doctors.
row.field_list_description: By joining a clinical trial or study, you may get access to a new drug, or a chance to see world-renowned doctors. You are also helping future rare cancer patients by helping researchers today.

row.title: What are rare nerve tumors?
row.field_page_description: Rare nerve tumors can form in the nervous system anywhere in the body. They can form in nerve cells or in cells around the nerve cells, like Schwann or perineurial cells.
row.field_list_description: Rare nerve tumors can form in the nervous system anywhere in the body. They can form in nerve cells or in cells around the nerve cells, like Schwann or perineurial cells.

row.title: Frederick National Laboratory for Cancer Research Acquisitions
row.field_page_description: The NCI Office of Acquisition administers contracts for the Frederick National Laboratory for Cancer Research. Browse opportunities for subcontracting and learn more about the prime contract competition.
row.field_list_description: The Frederick National Laboratory for Cancer Research has a primary contractor and subcontracts. Browse opportunities for subcontracting and learn more about the prime contract competition.

row.title: About the Office of Acquisitions
row.field_page_description: NCI’s Office of Office of Acquisitions (OA) has several divisions that handle contracting and acquisitions for different parts of the National Cancer Institute.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn more about the Office of Acquisitions, its divisions, and how to contact the office.
row.field_list_description: Learn more about the Office of Acquisitions, its divisions, and how to contact the office.

row.title: Malignant Mesothelioma—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Malignant mesothelioma is a cancer of the thin tissue (mesothelium) that lines the lung, chest wall, and abdomen. The major risk factor for mesothelioma is asbestos exposure. Start here to find information on malignant mesothelioma treatment.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about Malignant Mesothelioma.

row.title: Statins and Cancer Prevention
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet about results from animal research and ongoing observational studies of people taking statins that suggest that these drugs may lower the risk of certain cancers.
row.field_list_description: A fact sheet about results from animal research and ongoing observational studies of people taking statins that suggest that these drugs may lower the risk of certain cancers, including colorectal and skin cancers.

row.title: Hyperthermia in Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet that defines hyperthermia (treating tumors with heat) and its side effects.

row.title: Uterine Cancer—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Uterine cancers can be of two types: endometrial cancer (common) and uterine sarcoma (rare). Endometrial cancer can often be cured. Uterine sarcoma is often more aggressive and harder to treat. Start here to find information on uterine cancer treatment, causes and prevention, screening, research, and statistics.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about uterine cancer.

row.title: Myeloproliferative Neoplasms—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Myeloproliferative neoplasms and myelodysplastic syndromes are diseases in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. Sometimes both conditions are present. Start here to find information on myeloproliferative neoplasms treatment.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about Myeloproliferative Neoplasms.

row.title: Pancreatic Cancer—Patient Version
row.field_page_description: Pancreatic cancer can form in exocrine cells and neuroendocrine cells. The exocrine type is more common and is usually found at an advanced stage. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are less common but have a better prognosis. Start here to find information on pancreatic cancer treatment, research, and statistics.
row.field_feature_card_description: Treatment options depend on how far the cancer has spread.
row.field_list_description: NCI's gateway for information about pancreatic cancer.

row.title: Antiperspirants/Deodorants and Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: A fact sheet describing studies on whether there is a link between underarm antiperspirants or deodorants and breast cancer.

row.title: Moving Beyond Breast Cancer Videos
row.field_page_description: Several breast cancer survivors discuss their journey and offer tips and advice to help cope with the challenges of recovery.

row.title: NCTN: NCI’s National Clinical Trials Network
row.field_page_description: Information about the National Clinical Trial Network's infrastructure and a synopsis of how NCTN improves the speed and efficiency of cancer clinical trials.
row.field_feature_card_description: An overview of NCI's state-of-the-art clinical trials infrastructure.
row.field_list_description: Information about NCI's National Clinical Trial Network (NCTN), a collection of organizations and clinicians that coordinates and supports cancer clinical trials at more than 3,000 sites across the United States and Canada.

row.title: Exposure to Secondhand Smoke Plummets, but Disparities Persist
row.field_short_title: Exposure to Secondhand Smoke Plummets, but Disparities Persist
row.field_page_description: Second-hand smoke exposure has fallen by 50 percent since 1999, a new study finds, but millions are still routinely exposed to secondhand smoke.
row.field_feature_card_description: Second-hand smoke exposure has fallen by 50 percent since 1999, a new study finds, but millions are still routinely exposed to secondhand smoke.

row.title: Health Communications Publications
row.field_page_description: Publications about best practices in health communication program planning, developed by the National Cancer Institute for health professionals.

row.title: Genetic Studies Yield Clues to Treatment-Related Side Effects in Children with Cancer
row.field_short_title: Genetic Studies Yield Clues to Treatment-Related Side Effects in Children with Cancer
row.field_page_description: Researchers have identified genetic variations in children with brain cancer that increased their risk of rapid hearing loss after treatment.
row.field_feature_card_description: Researchers have identified genetic variations in children with brain cancer that increased their risk of rapid hearing loss after treatment.

row.title: Special Spotlight: Widely Acclaimed Cancer Disparities Researcher, Claudia R. Baquet, MD, MPH, Retires from University of Maryland Baltimore School of Medicine
row.field_short_title: Special Spotlight: Widely Acclaimed Cancer Disparities Researcher, Claudia R. Baquet, Retires
row.field_page_description: Dr. Claudia R. Baquet, an internationally recognized expert in cancer health disparity research and a former NCI/CRCHD grantee, announces her retirement from the University of Maryland Baltimore School of Medicine.
row.field_feature_card_description: Dr. Claudia R. Baquet, a former NCI/CRCHD grantee, announces her retirement.

row.title: Divide and Conquer: The Molecular Diagnosis of Cancer
row.field_short_title: Divide and Conquer: The Molecular Diagnosis of Cancer
row.field_page_description: CCG promotes the transformation of cancer diagnosis and treatment through genomics. Using a “team science” approach, CCG supports research in structural, functional, and computational genomics that provide data and resources to the cancer research community.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn more about the vision of CCG's Director, Louis M. Staudt, M.D., Ph.D., in this Director's Note.

row.title: American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Recognizes TCGA’s Importance in the Past Decade and in Tumor Biology
row.field_short_title: ASCO Recognizes TCGA’s Importance in the Past Decade and in Tumor Biology
row.field_page_description: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) highlighted TCGA’s role in advancing knowledge about cancer genes, pathways, and subtypes, in its 2015 Annual Report on Progress Against Cancer.

row.title: Diet
row.field_page_description: Information about certain foods, minerals, and other parts of a person's diet and their associations with reducing or increasing the risk of cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Scientists have studied many dietary components to see if they raise or lower the risk of cancer.

row.title: Legal Requirements
row.field_page_description: Research grants are subject to many requirements from a variety of legal authorities, with the broadest being the U.S. Constitution.
row.field_feature_card_description: Learn about the legal requirements research grants are subject to.

row.title: CTRP System Access and Training
row.field_page_description: Find Clinical Trials Reporting Program (CTRP) user guides, resources, and contact information.

row.field_page_description: TCGA's Study of Adrenocortical Carcinoma
row.field_feature_card_description: TCGA's Study of Adrenocortical Carcinoma
row.field_list_description: A summary of TCGA's study of adrenocortical carcinoma (adrenal cortex cancer), including what was known prior to the study and main findings from the characterization and analysis.

row.title: Aggressive Prostate Cancer Subtype More Common Than Expected
row.field_short_title: Aggressive Prostate Cancer Subtype More Common Than Expected
row.field_page_description: Some men with advanced prostate cancer may be more likely than previously thought to develop a more aggressive form of the disease, a new study shows. As this Cancer Currents post reports, the subtype, called t-SCNC, was linked with shorter survival.
row.field_feature_card_description: Subtype linked with shorter survival than others.
row.field_list_description: Researchers have found that men with advanced prostate cancer may be more likely than previously thought to develop a more aggressive form of the disease. The subtype, called t-SCNC, was linked with shorter survival than other subtypes.

row.title: TCGA's Study of Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma
row.field_short_title: TCGA's Study of Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma
row.field_page_description: A summary of TCGA's study of papillary renal cell (kidney) carcinoma, including what was known prior to the study and main findings from the characterization and analysis.

row.field_feature_card_description: TCGA's Study of Hepatocellular Carcinoma
row.field_list_description: A summary of TCGA's study of hepatocellular (liver) carcinoma, including what was known prior to the study and main findings from the characterization and analysis.

row.title: TCGA's Study of Lung Adenocarcinoma
row.field_page_description: TCGA's Study of Lung Adenocarcinoma
row.field_feature_card_description: TCGA's Study of Lung Adenocarcinoma
row.field_list_description: A summary of TCGA's study of lung adenocarcinoma, including what was known prior to the study and main findings from the characterization and analysis.

row.title: TCGA's Study of Paraganglioma & Pheochromocytoma
row.field_page_description: TCGA's Study of Paraganglioma & Pheochromocytoma

row.field_list_description: A summary of TCGA's study of paraganglioma & pheochromocytoma, including what was known prior to the study and main findings from the characterization and analysis.

row.title: Working with NCI Divisions, Offices and Centers to Advance Global Cancer Research
row.field_short_title: Working with NCI Divisions, Offices and Centers to Advance Global Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: According to recently released global cancer burden statistics, an estimated 18.1 new cancer cases and 9.6 million deaths from cancer were expected in 2018. Read CGH's newest Spotlight Blog to see how we are Working with NCI Divisions, Offices, and Centers to Advance Global Cancer Research.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI's Center for Global Health supports efforts at NCI and elsewhere to further research that will lessen the burden of cancer worldwide.
row.field_list_description: The Center for Global Health is partnering with NCI divisions, offices, and centers, and partners around the world to recognize World Cancer Research Day (WCRD) on September 24. WCRD is a global initiative to increase awareness about the importance of cancer research and the dedication of cancer researchers worldwide.

row.title: Women's Cancers Program (WCP)
row.field_page_description: CGH is committed to build capacity for prevention, screening, detection, diagnosis and treatment of women’s cancers in LMICs.
row.field_feature_card_description: CGH is committed to build capacity for prevention, screening, detection, diagnosis and treatment of women’s cancers in LMICs.

row.title: Breast Cancer Steering Committee Roster
Cancer Staging
row.field_page_description: Staging is the process of determining how much cancer is within the body (tumor size) and if it has spread. Learn about the TNM Staging system and other ways that stage is described.
row.field_feature_card_description: Stage describes details about your cancer, such as tumor size and if it has spread. Staging guides decisions about treatment.
row.field_list_description: Staging is the process of determining details about your cancer, such as tumor size and if it has spread. The stage guides decisions about treatment.

row.title: Spotlight on Scientists Videos
row.field_page_description: Researchers, fellows, principal investigators, and medical doctors provide inspiration and advice to students interested in medical research.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI-supported scientists explain key aspects of basic and clinical cancer research; describe how and why they became cancer researchers, with advice for students; and offer their perspectives on a range of challenges and achievements in cancer research.
row.field_list_description: NCI scientists, from postdoctoral fellows to principal investigators, discuss various topics including their personal backgrounds, how they came to be in the field of cancer research, their current projects, and a look to the future of medical oncology.

row.title: Managing Cancer Care
row.field_page_description: Information on choosing a doctor or treatment facility, home care, financial help, insurance coverage, end-of-life planning, and resources to help you avoid scams.
row.field_feature_card_description: Information on choosing a doctor or treatment facility, home care, financial help, insurance coverage, end-of-life planning, and resources to help you avoid scams.
row.field_list_description: Helpful information about health care services, insurance and finance options, advanced planning, home care, and how to avoid scams with print and online sources of health information.

row.title: Hormone Therapy to Treat Cancer
row.field_page_description: Hormone therapy is a treatment that slows or stops the growth of breast and prostate cancers that use hormones to grow. Learn about the types of hormone therapy and side effects that may happen.
row.field_feature_card_description: Hormone therapy is a treatment that slows or stops the growth of breast and prostate cancers that use hormones to grow. Learn about the types of hormone therapy and side effects that may happen.

row.title: Step 3: Peer Review and Funding Outcomes
row.field_short_title: Step 3: Peer Review and Funding Outcomes
row.field_page_description: The NCI review process seeks to achieve a balanced grant portfolio, that addresses scientific priorities. Learn about NCI’s peer review for grant applications.
row.field_feature_card_description: Each grant application is reviewed for scientific and technical merit.
row.field_list_description: The NIH Peer Review process provides fair, independent, expert, and timely review of each grant application.

row.title: Contact The Center for Global Health
row.field_page_description: The CGH U.S. offices is located at 9609 Medical Center Drive, Rockville, MD 20892.

row.title: Genitourinary Cancers Steering Committee Roster
Head and Neck Steering Committee
row.field_page_description: The Head and Neck Steering Committee addresses the design, prioritization and evaluation of concepts for phase II and phase III clinical trials in adult head and neck cancers.
row.field_feature_card_description: The Head and Neck Steering Committee evaluates and prioritizes concepts for phase 3 and large phase 2 therapeutic clinical trials.
row.field_list_description: The Head and Neck Steering Committee evaluates and prioritizes concepts for phase 3 and large phase 2 therapeutic clinical trials to be conducted in the NCI National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN).

row.title: "Flipping the Switch": An Interview with Dr. Mark Gilbert, Chief of NIH’s Neuro-Oncology Branch
row.field_short_title: "Flipping the Switch": Dr. Mark Gilbert Interview
row.field_page_description: NCI's Dr. Mark Gilbert discusses new developments in neuro-oncology and the priorities of the Neuro-Oncology Branch.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI's Dr. Mark Gilbert discusses new developments in neuro-oncology and the priorities of the Neuro-Oncology Branch.

row.title: Surgery to Treat Cancer
row.field_page_description: Surgery, when used to treat cancer, is a procedure in which a surgeon removes cancer from your body. Learn how surgery is performed and different types of surgery.
row.field_feature_card_description: Surgery, when used to treat cancer, is a procedure in which a surgeon removes cancer from your body. Learn the different ways that surgery is used against cancer and what you can expect before, during, and after surgery.
row.field_list_description: When used to treat cancer, surgery is a procedure in which a surgeon removes cancer from your body. Learn the different ways that surgery is used against cancer and what you can expect before, during, and after surgery.

row.title: NCI CCT K Awards Evaluation
row.field_short_title: Evaluation of the Career Development (K) Awards Program
row.field_page_description: A recent evaluation of CCT's K Awards Program tracked participants' subsequent outcomes and demonstrated the program had a positive influence on their research careers.
row.field_feature_card_description: A recent evaluation of CCT's K Awards Program tracked participants' subsequent outcomes and demonstrated the program had a positive influence on their research careers.

row.title: Cancer Prevention Research
row.field_page_description: NCI’s prevention research has a broad focus, from identifying environmental and lifestyle factors that influence cancer risk to studying the biology of how cancer develops and studying ways to disseminate prevention interventions.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI-supported scientists are studying cancer risk, cancer biology, prevention interventions, and more.

row.title: Researcher Interview: Elaine Mardis
row.field_page_description: Elaine Mardis Ph.D., Professor of Medicine at Washington University School of Medicine, discusses her translational research applying genomics techniques to clinical trials, and forecasts the future of team science and cancer genomics.

row.title: Research Performance Progress Report (RPPR)
row.field_page_description: Find more information about the RPPR, which documents recipient accomplishments and compliance with terms of award.
row.field_feature_card_description: Find more information about the RPPR, which documents recipient accomplishments and compliance with terms of award.

row.title: Hormones
row.field_page_description: information about the female hormones that are associated with an increased risk of certain cancers.

row.title: Progress in Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: Through its Annual Report to the Nation and other reports and publications, the National Cancer Institute – leader of the National Cancer Program – marks the progress that’s been made by the cancer research community.

row.title: Refining Preoperative Therapy for Locally Advanced Rectal Cancer
row.field_short_title: Refining Preoperative Therapy for Locally Advanced Rectal Cancer
row.field_page_description: In the PROSPECT trial, patients with locally advanced, resectable rectal cancer will be randomly assigned to receive either standard neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy or neoadjuvant FOLFOX chemotherapy, with chemoradiation reserved for nonresponders.
row.field_feature_card_description: In the PROSPECT trial, patients with locally advanced, resectable rectal cancer will be randomly assigned to receive either standard neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy or neoadjuvant FOLFOX chemotherapy, with chemoradiation reserved for nonresponders.
row.field_list_description: In the current clinical trial, dubbed PROSPECT, patients with locally advanced, resectable rectal cancer will be randomly assigned to receive either standard neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy or neoadjuvant FOLFOX chemotherapy, with chemoradiation reserved for those patients who cannot tolerate or do not respond to FOLFOX chemotherapy.

row.title: International Bilateral Programs for Collaborative Scientific Research
row.field_short_title: International Bilateral Programs for Collaborative Scientific Research
row.field_page_description: The International Bilateral Programs for Collaborative Scientific Research seeks to enhance the global activities of NCI’s intramural researchers and grantees through co-funded support for collaborative research between NIH and international scientific research agencies.
row.field_feature_card_description: The United States–China Program for Biomedical Research Cooperation co-funds U.S. and Chinese scientists to conduct collaborative basic and translational biomedical research.

row.title: Center for Global Health Staff
row.field_page_description: Contact information for NCI's Center for Global Health leadership and staff. CGH is a collaborative team of over 40 cancer researchers, scientists, and communication experts.
